To make matters worse, Gilbert suggested a plot in which people fell in love against their wills after taking a magic lozenge – a scenario that Sullivan had previously rejected, and he now rejected the "lozenge plot" again. Gilbert eventually came up with a new idea and began work in May 1884.<ref>Ainger, pp. 230–33</ref>
The company produced the first revival of ''The Sorcerer'', together with ''Trial by Jury'', and matinees of ''The Pirates of Penzance'' played by a cast of children, while waiting for the new work to be completed. This became the partnership's most successful opera, ''[[The Mikado]]'', which opened in March 1885.<ref name=Wilson13>Wilson and Lloyd, p. 13</ref> The piece satirised British institutions by setting them in a fictional Japan. At the same time, it took advantage of the Victorian craze for the exotic Far East using the "picturesque" scenery and costumes of Japan.<ref>Jones, Brian. "Japan in London 1885", ''W. S. Gilbert Society Journal'', issue 22, Winter 2007, pp. 686–96</ref> ''The Mikado'' became the partnership's longest-running hit, enjoying 672 performances at the Savoy Theatre, the second longest run for any work of musical theatre up to that time,<ref>The longest-running piece of musical theatre was the [[operetta]] ''[[Les Cloches de Corneville]]'', which held that position until the record-breaking run of ''[[Dorothy (opera)|Dorothy]]'' in 1886. See Gillan, Don. [http://www.stagebeauty.net/th-frames.html?http&&&www.stagebeauty.net/th-longr.html "Longest Running Plays in London and New York"], Stagebeauty.net, 2007, accessed 8 October 2009</ref> and it was extraordinarily popular in the U.S. and worldwide.<ref name=DNB/> It remains the most frequently performed Savoy opera.<ref>Bradley, Ian. [http://www.hcs.harvard.edu/hrgsp/old/productions/mik97/mik97hist.htm Note on the popularity of ''The Mikado''], Hcs.harvard.edu, accessed 27 May 2009</ref><ref>[[John Kenrick (theatre writer)|Kenrick, John.]] [http://www.musicals101.com/gilbert3.htm "G&S101: G&S Story: Part III"], Musicals101.com, accessed 8 October 2009</ref> Beginning with ''The Mikado'', [[Hawes Craven]], the designer of the sets for [[Henry Irving]]'s spectacular [[Shakespeare]] productions at the [[Lyceum Theatre, London|Lyceum Theatre]], designed all of the D'Oyly Carte sets until 1893.<ref>Craven had earlier designed the sets for Act II of ''Princess Ida'': see Rollins and Witts, p. viii</ref>
The partnership's next opera was ''[[Ruddigore]]'', which opened in January 1887. It satirised and used elements of Victorian stock [[melodrama]].<ref>Walmisley, Guy H. and Claude A. [http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/ruddigore/html/intro.html Excerpt about ''Ruddigore''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091001162103/http://math.boisestate.edu/gas///ruddigore/html/intro.html |date=1 October 2009 }} from ''Tit-Willow; or Notes and Jottings on Gilbert and Sullivan Operas'' (London: 1964), reproduced at The Gilbert and Sullivan Archive, 9 January 2005 accessed 12 October 2009</ref> The piece, though profitable, was a relative disappointment after the extraordinary success of ''The Mikado''.<ref>Jacobs, p. 248</ref> When ''Ruddigore'' closed after a run of only nine months, the company mounted revivals of earlier Gilbert and Sullivan operas for almost a year. After another attempt by Gilbert to persuade Sullivan to set a "lozenge plot", Gilbert met his collaborator half way by writing a serio-comic plot for ''[[The Yeomen of the Guard]]'', which premiered in October 1888.<ref>Ainger, p. 270</ref> The opera was a success, running for over a year, with strong New York and touring productions. During the run, in March 1889, Sullivan again expressed reluctance to write another comic opera, asking if Gilbert would write a "dramatic work on a larger musical scale".<ref>Jacobs, p. 287</ref> Gilbert declined, but offered a compromise that Sullivan ultimately accepted: The two would write a light opera for the Savoy, and at the same time, Sullivan could work on a grand opera (''[[Ivanhoe (opera)|Ivanhoe]]'') for a new theatre that Carte was constructing to present British grand opera.<ref>Jacobs, p. 288</ref> The new comic opera was ''[[The Gondoliers]]'', which opened in December 1889 and became one of the partnership's greatest successes.<ref>Baily, p. 344</ref> After Carte's first wife died in 1885, Carte married Helen Lenoir in 1888, who was, by this time, nearly as important in managing the company as Carte himself.<ref name=helenDNB/>
[[File:Gondo1990.jpg|right|220px]] During these years, the company's high production values, and the quality of the operas, created a national and international taste for them, and the company mounted touring productions throughout the provinces, in America (generally managed by Helen), Europe<ref name=DNB/> and elsewhere.<ref name=Bentley/> [[Queen Victoria]] honoured the company by calling for a [[Royal Command Performance]] of ''The Gondoliers'' at [[Windsor Castle]] in 1891.<ref name=Burgess/> [[George Bernard Shaw|Bernard Shaw]], writing in ''[[The World (journal)|The World]]'' in October 1893, commented, "Those who are old enough to compare the Savoy performances with those of the dark ages, taking into account the pictorial treatment of the fabrics and colours on the stage, the cultivation and intelligence of the choristers, the quality of the orchestra, and the degree of artistic good breeding, so to speak, expected from the principals, best know how great an advance has been made by Mr. D'Oyly Carte."<ref>"Utopian Gilbert and Sullivan", ''The World'', 11 October 1893, reprinted in Laurence, pp. 975–76</ref>
===The Carpet Quarrel and the end of the partnership=== On 22 April 1890, during the run of ''The Gondoliers'', Gilbert discovered that maintenance expenses for the theatre, including a new £500<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.measuringworth.com/ukcompare/result.php?use%5B%5D=CPI&use%5B%5D=DEFIND&use%5B%5D=WAGE&use%5B%5D=GDPCP&use%5B%5D=GDPC&year_early=1890&pound71=500&shilling71=&pence71=&amount=500&year_source=1890&year_result=2006 |title=Approximately £37,818.60 in 2006 prices |access-date=19 October 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714064621/http://www.measuringworth.com/ukcompare/result.php?use%5B%5D=CPI&use%5B%5D=DEFIND&use%5B%5D=WAGE&use%5B%5D=GDPCP&use%5B%5D=GDPC&year_early=1890&pound71=500&shilling71=&pence71=&amount=500&year_source=1890&year_result=2006 |archive-date=14 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> carpet for the front lobby of the theatre, were being charged to the partnership instead of borne by Carte. Gilbert confronted Carte, and Carte refused to reconsider the accounts: Even though the amount of the charge was not great, Gilbert felt it was a moral issue involving Carte's integrity, and he could not look past it. Gilbert wrote in a letter to Sullivan that "I left him with the remark that it was a mistake to kick down the ladder by which he had risen".<ref name=Crothcarpet/> Helen Carte wrote that Gilbert had addressed Carte "in a way that I should not have thought you would have used to an offending menial."<ref>Stedman, p. 270</ref> Gilbert brought a lawsuit, but Sullivan sided with Carte, who was building the [[Palace Theatre, London|Royal English Opera House]], the inaugural production of which was to be Sullivan's forthcoming grand opera.<ref name=DNB/> Gilbert won the suit, but the partnership disbanded.<ref name=vowed>Shepherd, Marc. "Introduction: Historical Context", ''The Grand Duke'', p. vii, New York: Oakapple Press, 2009; linked at [http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/grand_duke/html/index.html "The Grand Duke"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090620070606/http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/grand_duke/html/index.html |date=20 June 2009 }}. ''The Gilbert and Sullivan Archive'', accessed 7 July 2009</ref>
Sullivan's opera, ''[[Ivanhoe (opera)|Ivanhoe]]'', had a successful run, but no other operas shared Carte's new opera house, and so the theatre soon failed.<ref name=DNB/> Carte sold the opera house, and it eventually became the [[Palace Theatre, London|Palace Theatre]].<ref>[http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/PalaceTheatre.htm The Palace Theatre] at the Arthur Lloyd theatre site, accessed 13 October 2009</ref><ref>See "The Palace Theatre", ''The Times'', 12 December 1892, p. 7; "The Theatres in 1892", ''The Times'', 31 December 1892, p. 3; and "Palace Theatre as Cinema. Stage Plays also to be Given", ''The Times'', 31 January 1921, p. 8</ref>
After ''The Gondoliers'' closed in 1891, Gilbert withdrew the performance rights to his libretti and vowed to write no more operas for the Savoy.<ref name=vowed/> The D'Oyly Carte company turned to new writing teams for the Savoy, first producing ''[[The Nautch Girl]]'', by [[George Dance (dramatist)|George Dance]], [[Frank Desprez]] and [[Edward Solomon]], which ran for a satisfying 200 performances in 1891–92. Next was a revival of Solomon and [[Sydney Grundy]]'s ''[[The Vicar of Bray (opera)|The Vicar of Bray]]'', which played through the summer of 1892. Grundy and Sullivan's ''[[Haddon Hall (opera)|Haddon Hall]]'' then held the stage until April 1893.<ref name=joseph111>Joseph (1994), p. 111</ref> While the company presented new pieces and revivals at the Savoy, Carte's touring companies continued to play throughout Britain and in America. In 1894, for example, Carte had four companies touring Britain and one playing in America.<ref>"The Savoyards on Tour", ''The Sketch'', 13 June 1894, pp. 373–74</ref>
[[File:Comic Opera at the Savoy.png|left|thumb|[[George Grossmith|Grossmith]] comforts [[Richard D'Oyly Carte|Carte]] after failure of ''[[The Grand Duke]]''.]] Gilbert's aggressive, though successful, legal action had embittered Sullivan and Carte, but the partnership had been so profitable that the Cartes eventually sought to reunite Gilbert and Sullivan. The reconciliation finally came through the efforts of [[Chappell & Co.|Tom Chappell]], who published the sheet music to the Savoy operas.<ref>Wolfson, p. 7</ref> In 1893, the company produced the penultimate Gilbert and Sullivan collaboration, ''[[Utopia, Limited]]''. While ''Utopia'' was being prepared, the company produced ''[[Jane Annie]]'', by [[J. M. Barrie]] and [[Arthur Conan Doyle]], with music by [[Ernest Ford]]. Despite the popularity of Barrie and Conan Doyle, the show was a flop, closing in July 1893 after only 51 performances.<ref>Tillett, Selwyn. "Jane Annie", in ''Sullivan Society Journal'', 1993 centenary issue on ''Utopia, Limited''</ref> ''Utopia'' was the Savoy's most expensive production to date, but it ran for a comparatively disappointing 245 performances, until June 1894, turning a very modest profit.<ref name=joseph111/> The company then played first ''[[Mirette (opera)|Mirette]]'', composed by [[André Messager]], then ''[[The Chieftain]]'', by [[Francis Burnand|F. C. Burnand]] and Sullivan. These ran for 102 and 97 performances, respectively.<ref>Rollins and Witts, pp. 14–15</ref> After ''The Chieftain'' closed, the company toured the London suburbs, while Carte leased the Savoy Theatre to the [[Carl Rosa Opera Company]]. The theatre was dark during the summer of 1895, reopening in November for a revival of ''[[The Mikado]]''.<ref name=Wilson52>Wilson and Lloyd, p. 52</ref> This was followed by ''[[The Grand Duke]]'', in 1896, which ran for 123 performances and was Gilbert and Sullivan's only financial failure. ''The Gondoliers'' turned out to be Gilbert and Sullivan's last big hit, and after ''The Grand Duke'', the two men never collaborated again.<ref name=joseph111/>
In 1894, Carte had hired his son, [[Rupert D'Oyly Carte|Rupert]], as an assistant. Rupert assisted Mrs. Carte and [[W. S. Gilbert]] with the first revival of ''[[The Yeomen of the Guard]]'' at the Savoy in May 1897.<ref>''[[New York Post]]'', 7 January 1948</ref> Throughout the later 1890s, Carte's health was declining, and Mrs. Carte assumed more and more of the responsibilities of running the opera company. She profitably managed the theatre and the provincial touring companies.<ref name=helenDNB/> The Savoy's shows during this period received comparatively short runs, including ''[[His Majesty (comic opera)|His Majesty]]'' (1897), ''[[The Grand Duchess of Gerolstein]]'' (1897), ''[[The Beauty Stone]]'' (1898) and ''[[The Lucky Star]]'' (1899), as well as revivals of the Gilbert and Sullivan operas.<ref name=Wilson52/> Sullivan's ''The Beauty Stone'' ran for only 50 performances.<ref>Rollins and Witts, p. 17</ref> In 1899, the Savoy finally had a new success, with Sullivan and [[Basil Hood]]'s ''[[The Rose of Persia]]'', which ran for 213 performances.<ref>Rollins and Witts, p. 18</ref> Neither Carte nor Sullivan lived to see the production of Sullivan and Hood's ''[[The Emerald Isle]]'' (1901), for which [[Edward German]] completed the score.<ref>''The Times'' obituary, 4 April 1901, p. 8</ref>
===Early 20th century=== Carte left his theatre, opera company and hotels to his wife, who assumed full control of the family businesses.<ref>Joseph (1994), p. 133</ref> Her London and touring companies continued to present the Savoy operas in Britain and overseas.<ref>Rollins and Witts, pp. 111–27</ref> She leased the Savoy Theatre to [[William Greet]] in 1901 and oversaw his management of the company's revival of ''Iolanthe'' and the production of several new comic operas, including ''[[The Emerald Isle]]'' (1901), ''[[Merrie England (opera)|Merrie England]]'' (1902) and ''[[A Princess of Kensington]]'' (with music by [[Edward German]], libretto by [[Basil Hood]]), which ran for four months in early 1903 and then toured.<ref>Joseph (1994), p. 138</ref> When ''A Princess of Kensington'' closed at the Savoy, Mrs. Carte leased the theatre to other managements until 8 December 1906. The company's fortunes declined for a time, and by 1904 there was only a single touring company wending its way through the British provinces, when it took a seven-month South African tour.<ref name=Wilson52/>
In 1906–07, Mrs. Carte staged a repertory season at the Savoy Theatre, with Gilbert returning to direct.<ref>Joseph (1994), p. 146</ref> The season, which included ''Yeomen'', ''The Gondoliers'', ''Patience'' and ''Iolanthe'', was a sensation<ref name=Wilson52/> and led to another in 1908–09 including ''The Mikado'', ''Pinafore'', ''Iolanthe'', ''Pirates'', ''The Gondoliers'' and ''Yeomen''.<ref>Wilson and Lloyd, pp. 83–87</ref> Afterwards, however, Mrs. Carte's health prevented her from staging more London seasons.<ref>Carte, Bridget D'Oyly. Foreword to Mander, Raymond and Joe Mitchenson, ''A Picture History of Gilbert and Sullivan'', Vista Books, London, 1962</ref> She retired and leased the theatre to [[C. H. Workman]], and the company did not perform in London again until 1919, although it continued to tour throughout Britain.<ref>Joseph (1994), pp. 138 and 186</ref>
[[File:Rupert carte 1919.jpg|right|frame|[[Rupert D'Oyly Carte]]]] After Gilbert's death in 1911, the company continued to produce productions of the operas in repertory until 1982. In 1911, Helen Carte hired [[J. M. Gordon]] as stage manager. Gordon, who was promoted to stage director in 1922,<ref>''Rollins and Witts'', p. ii</ref> had been a member of the company and a stage manager under Gilbert's direction, and he fiercely preserved the company's performing traditions in exacting detail for 28 years.<ref>Stone, David (ed). [http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/whowaswho/G/GordonJM.htm J M Gordon] at ''Who Was Who in the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company'', accessed 21 December 2009</ref> Except for ''[[Ruddigore]]'', which underwent some cuts and received a new overture,<ref>''[[Cox and Box]]'' was cut and arranged into a short curtain raiser</ref> very few changes were made to the text and music of the operas as Gilbert and Sullivan had produced them, and the company stayed true to Gilbert's period settings. Even after Gordon's death, many of Gilbert's directorial concepts survived, both in the stage directions printed in the libretti and as preserved in company prompt books. Original choreography was also maintained.<ref>See, for instance, 1882 images of the Act II trio in ''Iolanthe'' in ''Mander and Michenson'', p. 65 and 1974 images of the same scene on the sleeve of D'Oyly Carte recording, Decca SKL 5188/9</ref> Some of the company's staging became accepted as traditional by Gilbert and Sullivan fans, and many of these traditional stagings are still imitated today in productions by both amateur and professional companies.<ref name=Bradley30/><ref name=Bradley61>Bradley (2005), p. 61</ref><ref name=Leonard>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article7035514.ece "Patricia Leonard: principal contralto of the D’Oyly Carte opera"]. ''[[The Times]]'', 22 February 2010</ref>
[[Helen Carte]] died in 1913, and Carte's son [[Rupert D'Oyly Carte]] inherited the company.<ref>Carte's older son, Lucas, was a barrister and took no part in the family businesses. He died of tuberculosis in 1907, aged 34. See Obituary of Lucas D'Oyly Carte, ''The Times'', 22 January 1907, p. 12</ref> During World War I, he was away serving in the [[Royal Navy]].<ref name=bettany/> According to H. M. Walbrook, "Through the years of the Great War [the company] continued to be on tour through the country, drawing large and grateful audiences everywhere. They helped to sustain the spirits of the people during that stern period, and by so doing they helped to win the victory."<ref>[http://math.boisestate.edu/GaS/books/walbrook/chap16.html Walbrook, H. M. ''Gilbert & Sullivan Opera, A History and a Comment'', Chapter XVI] (1920) London: F. V. White & Co. Ltd.</ref> The company also toured in North America several times, beginning with a Canadian tour in 1927.<ref name=Joseph160/>
Rupert D'Oyly Carte found the company's productions increasingly "dowdy", however, and on his return from the war, he determined to refresh them, bringing in new designers including W. Bridges-Adams for the sets, and, for the costumes, [[George Sheringham]] and [[Hugo Rumbold]]. He also commissioned new costumes from [[Percy Anderson]] who had worked with Gilbert and Richard D'Oyly Carte on the original productions of the later Savoy operas.<ref name=Wilson90>Wilson and Lloyd, p. 90</ref> [[Charles Ricketts]] redesigned sets and costumes for ''[[The Mikado]]'' (1926) and ''[[The Gondoliers]]'' (1929). His costumes for ''The Mikado'' were retained by all subsequent designers until 1982. In an interview in ''[[The Observer]]'' in August 1919, Carte set out his policy for staging the operas: "They will be played precisely in their original form, without any alteration to the words, or any attempt to bring them up to date."<ref>''The Observer'', 24 August 1919, p. 10</ref> This uncompromising declaration was modified in a later interview in which he said, "the plays are all being restaged. ... Gilbert's words will be unaltered, though there will be some freshness in the method of rendering them. Artists must have scope for their individuality, and new singers cannot be tied down to imitate slavishly those who made successes in the old days."<ref name=bettany/>
[[File:1919-20season.jpg|left|thumb|300px|[[Souvenir program]]me cover, 1919–20 season]] The main company made a triumphant return to London for the 1919–20 season at the [[Shaftesbury Theatre|Prince's Theatre]], playing most of the Gilbert and Sullivan operas in repertory and showing off the new sets and costumes.<ref>[http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/carte/1919/index.html Information about the 1919–20 D'Oyly Carte season] at The Gilbert and Sullivan Archive, accessed 20 November 2009</ref> The success of this season led to additional London seasons in 1919–20, 1921–22, 1924, and 1926; the company toured the rest of the year.<ref name=Joseph160>Joseph (1994), pp. 160 ''et seq.''</ref> Carte's first London season stimulated renewed interest in the operas, and by 1920 he had established a second, smaller company to tour smaller towns. It was disbanded in 1927, although the company often ran multiple tours simultaneously.<ref name=Wilson90/> For London seasons, Carte engaged guest conductors, first [[Geoffrey Toye]], then [[Malcolm Sargent]], who examined Sullivan's manuscript scores and purged the orchestral parts of accretions. So striking was the orchestral sound produced by Sargent that the press thought he had retouched the scores, and Carte had the pleasant duty of correcting their error. In a letter to ''[[The Times]]'', he noted that "the details of the orchestration sounded so fresh that some of the critics thought them actually new... the opera was played last night exactly as written by Sullivan."<ref>Carte, Rupert D'Oyly. ''The Times'', 22 September 1926, p. 8</ref> Carte also hired [[Harry Norris (conductor)|Harry Norris]], who started with the touring company, then was Toye's assistant before becoming musical director.
{{listen|filename=Major-General's Song.ogg|title=Major-General's Song|description=[[George Baker (record singer)|George Baker]] singing the ''[[Major-General's Song]]'' from the company's 1929 recording of ''Pirates'', conducted by [[Malcolm Sargent]]|format=[[OGG]]}} In 1917, the company made the first complete recording of a Gilbert and Sullivan opera, ''[[The Mikado]]'', for the [[Gramophone Company]] (later known as [[His Master's Voice]]). Rupert D'Oyly Carte supervised the company's recordings, including eight more acoustic recordings by 1924, and a series of complete electrical recordings in the late 1920s and early 1930s. There were additional recordings, in high fidelity, for [[Decca Records]], in the late 1940s and early 1950s and stereo recordings in the late 1950s and early 1960s, all supervised after Rupert's death by his daughter, [[Bridget D'Oyly Carte]].<ref>[http://www.cris.com/~oakapple/gasdisc/series.htm Links to detailed descriptions of the various series of D'Oyly Carte recordings] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080304054314/http://www.cris.com/~oakapple/gasdisc/series.htm |date=4 March 2008 }}. ''A Gilbert and Sullivan Discography'', accessed 10 January 2010</ref>
===The new Savoy Theatre=== [[File:D'oyly-carte-the-joy-of-three-generations-1921.jpg|thumb|220px|right|1921 cartoon: D'Oyly Carte audiences]] Rupert D'Oyly Carte also redesigned the Savoy Theatre. On 3 June 1929 the Savoy closed, and it was completely rebuilt to designs by Frank A. Tugwell with décor by [[Basil Ionides]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://math.boisestate.edu/GaS/carte/1929/index.html |title=Programme with photos of the new theatre and productions |access-date=8 October 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080527065615/http://math.boisestate.edu/GaS/carte/1929/index.html |archive-date=27 May 2008 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The old house had three tiers; the new one had two. The seating capacity was increased from 986 to 1,158. The theatre reopened 135 days later on 21 October 1929,<ref>Savoy Theatre programme note, September 2000</ref> with ''[[The Gondoliers]],'' designed by Ricketts and conducted by Sargent.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/carte/1929/index.html |title=Information about the 1929–20 season and the new designs |access-date=25 September 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080527065615/http://math.boisestate.edu/GaS/carte/1929/index.html |archive-date=27 May 2008 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[George Sheringham]] designed new productions that season of ''[[H.M.S. Pinafore]]'', ''[[The Pirates of Penzance]]'', and ''[[Patience (opera)|Patience]]'' (1929, with other designs contributed by [[Hugo Rumbold]]),<ref>[http://diamond.boisestate.edu/gas/carte/1929/index.html Illustrations of the Sheringham designs for ''Pinafore, Pirates'' and ''Patience'']</ref> and he later designed costumes for ''[[Trial by Jury]]'' and ''[[Iolanthe]]''.<ref>Rollins, Cyril and R. John Witts. ''The D'Oyly Carte Opera Company in Gilbert and Sullivan Operas'' (1961) London: Michael Joseph, Ltd.</ref>
The Savoy also hosted London seasons for the company in 1930–31, 1933, 1941, 1951, 1954, 1961, 1963–64, and 1975. London seasons at other theatres, mostly [[Sadler's Wells Theatre|Sadler's Wells]], included summer seasons from 1935 to 1939, 1942, 1947 to 1950, 1953, 1971, 1975, 1977 and 1980; and winter seasons in 1956–57, 1958–59, 1960–61, 1963–64, 1965–66, 1967–68, and then every winter between 1969–70 and 1981–82.<ref>In addition to the Savoy and Sadler's Wells, London seasons were at the Prince's Theatre (1956–57, 1958–59, and 1960–61); the [[Saville Theatre]] (1963–64, 1965–66 and 1967–68); the [[Royal Festival Hall]] (1971 and 1975); and the [[Adelphi Theatre]], 1981–82). See Rollins and Witts, pp. 180–86 and supplements.</ref> The company continued to tour the British provinces and abroad when it was not in London, and these tours also often included London suburbs.<ref>Rollins and Witts, pp. 154–82</ref> The company's musical director from 1929 (having been assistant musical director from 1925) was [[Isidore Godfrey]], who retained the position until 1968 and guest conducted the company in 1975, as part of the centenary season at the [[Savoy Theatre]]. Guest conductors during Godfrey's tenure were Sargent and [[Boyd Neel]]. [[Henry Lytton]] retired in 1934 after a quarter century as the principal comedian, and the company made a highly successful eight-month North American tour with its new principal comedian, [[Martyn Green]]. In 1938, many company members participated in the Technicolor film of ''The Mikado'' produced and conducted by Geoffrey Toye.<ref name=Wilson128>Wilson and Lloyd, p. 128</ref>
On 3 September 1939, at the outbreak of World War II, the British government ordered the immediate and indefinite closure of all theatres. Carte cancelled the autumn tour and disbanded the company.<ref>Joseph (1994), p. 246</ref> Theatres were permitted to reopen from 9 September,<ref>''The Times'', 9 September 1939, p. 9</ref> but it took some weeks to re-form the company. Some performers, including Martyn Green, were already committed elsewhere, and [[Grahame Clifford]] was engaged to play his roles. The company resumed touring, in [[Edinburgh]], on Christmas Day 1939.<ref>Rollins and Witts, p. 164</ref> The company continued to perform throughout the war, both on tour and in London, but in 1940 German bombing destroyed the sets and costumes for five of its shows: ''Cox and Box'', ''[[The Sorcerer]]'', ''[[H.M.S. Pinafore]]'', ''[[Princess Ida]]'' and ''Ruddigore''. The old productions of ''Pinafore'' and ''Cox and Box'' were recreated shortly after the war, and ''Ruddigore'' received a new production, planned by Carte but not seen until after his death. The other two operas took longer to rejoin the company's repertory.<ref>''Pinafore'' re-entered the repertory in July 1947, ''Cox and Box'' in the 1947/48 season, ''Ruddigore'' in November 1948, and ''Princess Ida'' in September 1954 (see Rollins and Witts, pp. 171–79 and VII–VIII). ''The Sorcerer'' was not revived until April 1971 (see ''The Times'', 2 April 1971, p. 10)</ref> On the other hand, for the first wartime season, [[Peter Goffin]], a protege of Carte's daughter, Bridget, had designed a new production of ''[[The Yeomen of the Guard]]'' first seen in January 1940, and his new ''[[Ruddigore]]'' debuted in 1948. A return to the U.S. in 1947 was very successful, and the company resumed frequent visits to America.<ref name=Wilson128/>
[[File:Mikado Ricketts.jpg|left|thumb|[[Charles Ricketts|Ricketts]]'s 1926 Mikado design]] Rupert died in 1948, leaving a strong company to his daughter [[Bridget D'Oyly Carte]].<ref>Joseph (1994), pp. 273–74</ref> She soon hired [[Frederic Lloyd]] as general manager. Bridget and Lloyd also took steps to keep the productions fresh, engaging designers to redesign the costumes and scenery. Peter Goffin, who had redesigned ''Yeomen'' (1939) and ''Ruddigore'' (1948) for the company, created new settings and costumes for Bridget for half a dozen more productions: ''[[The Mikado]]'' (1952; settings only, most of the celebrated [[Charles Ricketts]] costumes being retained), ''[[Patience (opera)|Patience]]'' (1957), ''[[The Gondoliers]]'' (1958), ''[[Trial by Jury]]'' (1959), ''[[H.M.S. Pinafore]]'' (1961; ladies' costumes) and ''[[Iolanthe]]'' (1961). A new production of ''[[Princess Ida]]'' in 1954 was designed by James Wade.<ref name=Wilson154>Wilson and Lloyd, p. 154</ref> [[Eleanor Evans]], however, was an example of one of the company's stage directors (from 1949 to 1953) who was said to be reluctant to update and freshen stagings.<ref>Watt, John. [http://pinafore.www3.50megs.com/k-sandford-fav.html "The Ones that I Like"], Interview with Sandford, c. 1972, at the Memories of the D'Oyly Carte website</ref> In 1957, Goffin designed a unit set for the company to facilitate touring, reducing the number of vans required to carry the scenery from twenty to nine.<ref name=Wilson154/> A 1957 review of ''Yeomen'' in ''The Times'' praised the production and marvelled at "the continued vitality of the Savoy operas", noting: "The opera remains enchanting; the singing seems, on the whole, better and more musical than that which one used to hear, say, 30 years since; and though the acting lacks some of the richly crusted performances of those days, it is perhaps none the worse for that".<ref>"The Lasting Charm of Gilbert and Sullivan", ''The Times'', 14 February 1957, p. 5</ref> In 1949, the company began a new series of recordings with Decca, featuring Green, who had returned to the company after the war, and continued the series with his successor, [[Peter Pratt]].<ref>Wilson and Lloyd, pp. 151 and 154</ref> The company cooperated with the production of the 1953 film ''[[The Story of Gilbert and Sullivan]]'', which used some former members of the company in the cast. In 1955, the company gave a seven-month tour to the U.S. to celebrate the 75th anniversary of its first American productions.<ref>Wilson and Lloyd, p. 175</ref> In 1959, the company began the tradition of holding a zany "last night" on the last evening of each London season.<ref name=Wilson154/>
===Later years and closing=== With the approaching end of the D'Oyly Carte monopoly on [[Gilbert and Sullivan]] performances, when the copyright on Gilbert's words expired in 1961 (Sullivan’s music had already come out of copyright at the end of 1950), Bridget D'Oyly Carte contributed the company and all its assets to an independent charitable trust. She endowed the trust with the company's scenery, costumes, band parts and other assets, together with a cash endowment, and supervised the production of operas on behalf of the trust until economic necessity forced the closure of the company in 1982.<ref>Bradley (2005), p. 29</ref> As it turned out, competing professional productions of Gilbert and Sullivan did not harm the company.<ref>Bradley (2005), p. 38</ref> Beginning in 1960, the company re-recorded all of the operas with Pratt's successor, [[John Reed (actor)|John Reed]],<ref>supported by such strong singers as [[Kenneth Sandford]], [[Donald Adams]], [[Thomas Round]], [[Valerie Masterson]], [[Jean Hindmarsh]] and [[Gillian Knight]]</ref> and also recorded a number of other Sullivan pieces. It made a [[The Mikado (1967 film)|cinema film of ''The Mikado'']] in 1966, and recorded for television broadcast its productions of ''Patience'' (1965) and ''H.M.S. Pinafore'' (1973).<ref>Shepherd, Mark. [http://gasdisc.oakapplepress.com/mik1966v.htm "The 1966 D'Oyly Carte ''Mikado'' Film"], [http://gasdisc.oakapplepress.com/pin1973v.htm "The 1973 D'Oyly Carte ''Pinafore'' Video"], and [http://gasdisc.oakapplepress.com/pat1965v.htm "The 1965 D'Oyly Carte ''Patience'' Broadcast"]. ''A Gilbert and Sullivan Discography'' (1999)</ref> It also supplied the soundtrack for a cartoon film of ''Ruddigore'' (1967).<ref>Shepherd, Mark. [http://gasdisc.oakapplepress.com/rudanim.htm "The Halas and Batchelor ''Ruddigore'' (1967)"]. ''A Gilbert and Sullivan Discography'' (1999)</ref> During the 1960s, the company gave five North American tours.<ref name=Wilson178>Wilson and Lloyd, p. 178</ref> A new stage director, [[Michael Heyland]], was hired in 1969, staying until 1978.<ref>Joseph (2007), p. 129</ref> Among his new productions were ''The Sorcerer'' in 1971, ''Utopia, Limited'' in 1975 and ''Iolanthe'' in 1977.<ref>Bradley (2005), p. 40. ''The Sorcerer'' had costume and set designs by [[Osbert Lancaster]]. See: "The Sorcerer to be revived", ''The Times'' , 5 March 1971, p. 10</ref>
In March and April 1975, after the regular London season at Sadler's Wells, the company moved to the Savoy Theatre for a fortnight's centennial performances, beginning on 25 March, the 100th anniversary of the first performance of ''Trial by Jury''. All thirteen surviving Gilbert and Sullivan operas were performed in chronological order. ''Trial by Jury'' was given four times, as a curtain raiser to ''The Sorcerer'', ''Pinafore'' and ''Pirates'' and as an afterpiece following ''The Grand Duke''.<ref name=Wilson178/> Before the first of the four performances of ''Trial'', a specially written curtain raiser by [[William Douglas-Home]], called ''Dramatic Licence'', was played by Peter Pratt as [[Richard D'Oyly Carte]], [[Kenneth Sandford]] as Gilbert and [[John Ayldon]] as Sullivan, in which Gilbert, Sullivan and Carte plan the birth of ''Trial'' in 1875; afterwards, the prime minister, [[Harold Wilson]], and Bridget D'Oyly Carte each gave a short speech.<ref>Forbes, Elizabeth. [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/kenneth-sandford-550525.html Kenneth Sandford obituary]. ''The Independent'', 23 September 2004</ref> A highlight of the season was a new staging of ''Utopia Limited'' (later given again at the [[Royal Festival Hall]]), its first revival by the company. ''The Grand Duke'' was given as a concert performance, with narration by the [[BBC]] presenter [[Richard Baker (broadcaster)|Richard Baker]]. [[Royston Nash]], who was at the company's musical helm from 1971 to 1979, conducted most of the performances, with [[Isidore Godfrey]] (''Pinafore'') and [[Charles Mackerras|Sir Charles Mackerras]] (''Pirates'' and ''Mikado'') as guest conductors. Princes Philip and Andrew saw ''The Gondoliers''. In the final performance of ''Trial by Jury'', the regular D'Oyly Carte chorus was augmented by fourteen former stars of the company: [[Sylvia Cecil]], [[Elsie Griffin]], [[Ivan Menzies]], [[John Dean (singer)|John Dean]], [[Radley Flynn]], Elizabeth Nickell-Lean, [[Ella Halman]], [[Leonard Osborn]], Cynthia Morey, [[Jeffrey Skitch]], Alan Barrett, Mary Sansom, [[Philip Potter]] and Gillian Humphreys.<ref>''The Savoyard'', Vol. 14, No. 2, September 1975</ref><ref>[http://diamond.boisestate.edu/gas/whowaswho/index.htm Biographies of all of these performers] are at the ''Who Was Who in the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company'' website</ref>
In 1977, during [[Queen Elizabeth II]]'s Jubilee Year, the company gave a [[Royal Command Performance]] of ''Pinafore'' at [[Windsor Castle]].<ref>Bradley (2005), p. 40</ref> The company visited Denmark in 1970, Rome in 1974, and gave its last American tours in 1976 and 1978. Its last tour, in [[Australasia]], conducted by the company's new musical director, Fraser Goulding, was a success in 1979.<ref name=Wilson178/> Throughout the 20th century, until 1982, the company toured, on average, for 35 weeks per year (in addition to its 13-week London seasons), fostering a "strong family atmosphere, reinforced by the number of marriages in the company and the fact that so many people stayed with it for so long."<ref>Bradley (2005), pp. 30–31</ref> Principal soprano [[Valerie Masterson]] married the company's principal flautist, Andrew March. She explained, "people didn't have flats or houses ... touring was your life."<ref>Bradley (2005), p. 31</ref> Throughout its history, the company maintained strict moral standards, and it was sometimes referred to as the "Savoy boarding school", enforcing policies regarding behaviour on and off stage, and even a dress code.<ref>Bradley (2005), pp. 31–34</ref> Soprano Cynthia Morey ascribed the strong affection that artists had for the company to "the unique family atmosphere engendered by the company's direct descent from its creators, Gilbert, Sullivan ... Richard D'Oyly Carte, followed by his widow, Helen, his son Rupert, and finally his granddaughter Bridget."<ref>Bradley (2005), p. 52</ref> The company also preserved, for over a century, what ''The Times'' called a "unique performance style, which may be summarised as a combination of good taste and good fun".<ref name=Leonard/>
[[File:DOCplanter.jpg|right|300px|thumb|Planter in front of the [[Savoy Hotel]] honouring the Carte family and colleagues]] After the 1979 tour, the rising costs of mounting year-round professional light opera without any government support, despite some generous private contributions, caused the company to accrue increasing losses.<ref>Bradley (2005), p. 42</ref> in 1980, the [[Arts Council of Great Britain|English Arts Council]]'s Music Panel and Touring Committee recommended that the Arts Council make a grant to the company, but this idea was rejected.<ref>Bradley (2005), p. 45</ref> The company's fans made an effort to raise private funds, but these were insufficient to make up the accelerating losses. In 1981, producer George Walker proposed to film the company performing all of the Gilbert and Sullivan operas but backed out.<ref>Bradley (2005), pp. 49–50</ref> Bridget D'Oyly Carte was forced to close the company in 1982, after a final London season in which John Reed and [[Valerie Masterson]] returned as guest artists.<ref>Joseph (1994), p. 358</ref><ref>Wilson and Lloyd, p. 208</ref> It gave its last performance on 27 February 1982, at the [[Adelphi Theatre]]. A three-LP recording of this performance was released, which included songs from all of the Gilbert and Sullivan operas.<ref>Shepherd, Marc. [http://gasdisc.oakapplepress.com/mc-doclastn.htm "D'Oyly Carte: The Last Night"]. ''A Gilbert and Sullivan Discography'', 16 July 2005, accessed 7 July 2010</ref> The company had operated nearly continuously for 107 years since the opening of ''Trial by Jury'' in 1875.<ref>Skow, John. [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,921136,00.html 1982 "Music: Final Curtain for D'Oyly Carte"]. ''Time'' magazine, 8 March 1982, accessed 7 July 2010</ref> Even after it closed, however, the company's productions continued to influence the productions of other companies.<ref name=Bradley30>Bradley (2005), p. 30. See also chapters four and six.</ref>
==Revivals of the company== Dame Bridget D’Oyly Carte died in 1985, leaving in her will a £1 million legacy to enable the company to be revived. The company secured sponsorship from [[Michael Bishop (businessman)|Sir Michael Bishop]], who later became chairman of the board of trustees, the [[Birmingham]] City Council and [[BMI (airline)|BMI]] British Midland Airways (of which Bishop is chairman). [[Richard Condon (impresario)|Richard Condon]] was appointed the revived company's first general manager, and [[Bramwell Tovey]] was its first musical director.<ref name=Bradley53>Bradley (2005), pp. 53–54 and 63</ref> In succeeding seasons, the company's productions of ''The Mikado'' and ''H.M.S. Pinafore'' were nominated for [[Olivier Awards]].<ref>Lisle, Nicola. "When the wheels came off the Carte", ''Classical Music'', 17 February 2007, p. 12</ref> From 1988 to 2003, the company mounted productions of the Gilbert and Sullivan operas on tour and in London, and it produced several operettas by [[Jacques Offenbach|Offenbach]], [[Franz Lehár|Lehár]] and [[Johann Strauss II|Strauss]]. Unlike the original company, which had regularly performed up to a dozen operas each year, 48 weeks a year, the new company generally presented only one or two operas in shorter seasons.<ref name=Bradley53/> In the first season, in 1988, the operas played were ''Iolanthe'' and ''The Yeomen of the Guard'', both starring [[Gillian Knight]]. The company made its debut at the [[Sunderland Empire Theatre]] on 29 April 1988, and, after touring, opened in London at the [[Cambridge Theatre]] in July.<ref>Kelly, Richard. "lolanthe", ''The Guardian'', 2 May 1988, p. 20; and Canning, Hugh. ''Cambridge Theatre – Iolanthe", ''The Guardian'', 14 July 1988, p. 17</ref> The press notices were good, particularly about the musical aspects of the new company; opinion was divided about the staging. ''The Observer'' thought the productions "miles superior to the later work of the old D'Oyly Carte; better designed, better lit ... better played and better sung."<ref>Ratcliffe, Michael. "Through a glass darkly", ''The Observer'', 17 July 1988, p. 40</ref> A review in ''The Guardian'' praised the musical standards, but added, "Gilbert and Sullivan is as much theatrical as musical entertainment and there remains a lot to be done on the visual side."<ref>Canning, Hugh. ''Cambridge Theatre – Iolanthe", ''The Guardian'', 14 July 1988, p. 17</ref>
The two operas presented in 1989 were ''The Mikado'' and ''The Pirates of Penzance.''<ref>Pettitt, Stephen. [http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:UKNB:LTIB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0F91033DA2E28F8E&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=1026E0A26AB6F6FF "Mask well sustained – Opera"]. ''The Times'', 13 September 1989; and Higgins, John. [http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:UKNB:LTIB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0F9103382901C2C6&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=1026E0A26AB6F6FF "Back with a new-found zip – Opera"]. ''The Times, 7 September 1989</ref> The new company's first three productions were broadly traditional in their staging. The ''Pirates'', however, marked a break with traditional presentations, with the setting a giant toy-box and a collapsible toy boat.<ref>Kenyon, Nicholas. "Pulsating pirate version", ''The Observer'', 16 April 1989, p. 43</ref> In 1990 the company presented campier versions of ''Pinafore'' and ''Trial'' (including a heavily pregnant Angelina) that were much criticised by the old company's fans, who complained that it was a betrayal of the legacy left by Bridget D'Oyly Carte.<ref>Bradley (2005), pp. 56–57</ref> The next season departed further from earnest presentations in its production of ''The Gondoliers'', which included a deeply corrugated stage floor, "startling", "surreal, primary coloured, starkly angled sets", gimmicky distracting business and generally staging that was considered "way over the top". It "was unveiled to storms of outraged booing".<ref name=canning>Canning, Hugh. [http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:UKNB:LSTB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0F929B59DE00F995&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=1026E0A26AB6F6FF "Light-arted operatic fare a la Carte – Opera"]. ''The Sunday Times'', 7 April 1991</ref> Most of the critics shared the public's disapproval of the production. ''The Times'' wrote, "The satiric point disappears in meretricious ado and humourless humour".<ref>Nightingale, Benedict. [http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:UKNB:LTIB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0F91EBAFC22040BD&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=1026E0A26AB6F6FF "Too little bold and witty are we – Comic Opera"]. ''The Times'', 10 April 1991. See also, Walters, Michael. [http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/newsletters/gossip/no38/gg38.html "Gilbertian Gossip"]. The Gilbert and Sullivan Newsletter, No. 38, Autumn 1992, accessed 7 June 2010 for a digest of other critical comment.</ref> Some critics, however, thought that it was time to sweep away "bad and lazy" traditions of the old company, calling the production "riotous, zany and subversive ... with a [[The Goon Show|Goonish]] or [[Monty Python's Flying Circus|Pythonesque]] sense of slapstick comedy", noting that "The girls are pretty and the boys are handsome, and they sing and dance with a youthful freshness".<ref name=canning/> Also in 1991, the company accepted an offer from the Alexandra Theatre, [[Birmingham]], to make its base there, although its pattern of spring national tours and summer London seasons was not affected.<ref>Seton, Craig. [http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:UKNB:LTIB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0F925AB7831F5FDE&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=1026E0A26AB6F6FF "D'Oyly Carte to move"]. ''The Times'', 9 May 1990. In 1997, following cuts in the funding of the theatre at Birmingham, the company moved its base to the Grand Theatre, Woverhampton: see Maddocks, Fiona. "Classical", ''The Observer '', 5 October 1997, p. 73</ref>
Another initiative was to stage a foreign operetta for the first time since Richard D'Oyly Carte's day, in what would be D'Oyly Carte's first co-production. The work chosen was ''[[Orpheus in the Underworld]]'', which [[Opera North]] presented in 1992 and D'Oyly Carte toured in 1993 as part of its 35-week tour celebrating the 150th anniversary of Sullivan's birth.<ref>[http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:UKNB:LTIB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0F91F07EE4EC7163&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=1026E0A26AB6F6FF "Going down – Arts Briefing"]. ''The Times'', 8 November 1991</ref> The innovation was welcomed,<ref>[[Rodney Milnes|Milnes, Rodney]]. [http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:UKNB:LTIB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0F91F9F237BF7059&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=1026E0A26AB6F6FF "All down to a hell of a good snigger – Opera"]. ''The Times'', 22 Monday, March 1993; and Sutcliffe, Tom. "Styx for Kicks", ''The Guardian'' 21 April 1993, p. A6</ref> receiving an Arts Council Grant,<ref>Bradley (2005), pp. 59–60</ref> and the company later presented ''[[Die Fledermaus]]'' (1994),<ref>Ratcliffe, Michael. "Operetta: Seeya", ''The Observer'', 26 March 1995, p. C12</ref> ''[[La Vie parisienne (operetta)|La Vie parisienne]]'' (1995)<ref>Finch, Hilary. [http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:UKNB:LTIB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0F924856759D8C0F&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=1026E0A26AB6F6FF "Joie de vivre falls in the pit – Opera"]. ''The Times'', 21 September 1995</ref> and ''[[The Count of Luxembourg]]'' (1997).<ref name=history>[http://www.doylycarte.org.uk/Inside_doyly_carte/recent_history.htm "Recent History"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050907045150/http://www.doylycarte.org.uk/Inside_doyly_carte/recent_history.htm |date=7 September 2005 }}. D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, accessed 7 June 2010</ref> Of the Savoy operas, the new company never staged ''The Sorcerer'', ''Patience'', ''Princess Ida'', ''Ruddigore'', ''Utopia'' and ''The Grand Duke'', stating that they lacked box-office potential.<ref name=Bradley62>Bradley (2005), p. 62</ref>
Unlike its predecessor, the new company was not a permanent ensemble with a recognisable style.<ref name=Bradley61/> Some performers appeared in several productions, but each production was cast anew, often with guest stars from British television in leading roles, with varying degrees of success.<ref>See, for example, [[Michael Billington (critic)|Billington, Michael]]. [https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2002/jul/02/theatre.artsfeatures1 "The Mikado"]. ''[[The Guardian]]'', 2 July 2002, accessed 6 June 2010</ref> The chorus and orchestra of the new company were much smaller than those of the old company: the chorus was reduced from 32 (or more) to 20, and the orchestra from 38 generally to 24.<ref name=Bradley62/><ref>See D'Oyly Carte programme booklets from Sadler's Wells 1977–78 season and the Savoy Theatre 2002 season.</ref> For a 1998 production of ''Pirates'' at the [[Queen's Theatre]], the orchestra was even smaller: ''The Guardian'' wrote, "The goings-on in the pit are dispiriting. Budgetary constraints have forced the company to re-write the score for a band of nine instrumentalists. They play well enough, but every one of Sullivan's parodies loses its clout."<ref>Ashley, Tim. "Tattered and tired Pirates", ''The Guardian,'' 30 December 1998, p. 2</ref> The company received a modest Arts Council grant in 1997 to keep it afloat and turned to private funding from [[Raymond Gubbay]] for London seasons beginning in 1998. Despite the lean forces, the company received generally favourable reviews over the next five years under the management of Ian Martin.<ref>Bradley (2005), pp. 63–67</ref> Although the new company's productions met with mixed reviews, some of its recordings have been well received.<ref>See, for example, Shepherd, Marc. [http://gasdisc.oakapplepress.com/yeondoc.htm "The New D'Oyly Carte ''Yeomen'' (1993)"]. ''A Gilbert and Sullivan Discography'' (1999), in which the company's new release is described as "the most important ''Yeomen'' recording made to date"</ref> Many of these recordings also restore music that had been cut by Gilbert and Sullivan or the company over the years.<ref>Bradley (2005), p. 69</ref> Gubbay felt over-committed by 2003 and pulled out. After fifteen years, with no Arts Council funding forthcoming, the company suspended productions in May 2003.<ref>Bradley (2005), p. 68</ref>
From May to July 2013, [[Scottish Opera]] produced a British touring production of ''The Pirates of Penzance'' in partnership with the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, although it was not reported what role the latter company took in the producing team. [[Richard Suart]] played Major-General Stanley and [[Nicholas Sharratt]] played Frederic.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20131022073413/http://www.scottishopera.org.uk/sites/default/files/pdf/FINAL%20Scottish%20Opera%20Sails%20Into%20Town%20On%20Pirate%20Adventure.pdf "Scottish Opera Sails into Town on ''Pirates'' Adventure"], Scottish Opera, April 2013</ref> ''The Daily Telegraph'', ''The Guardian'' and ''The Times'' each gave the production three out of five stars.<ref>Nickalls, Susan. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/opera/10064928/The-Pirates-of-Penzance-Theatre-Royal-Glasgow-review.html "''The Pirates of Penzance'', Theatre Royal, Glasgow, review"], ''The Daily Telegraph'' 17 May 2013; Molleson, Kate. [https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2013/may/16/pirates-of-penzance-review "''The Pirates of Penzance'' – review"], ''The Guardian'', 16 May 2013; and Jones, Sarah Urwin. [http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/arts/music/classical/article3766897.ece "''The Pirates of Penzance'' at the Theatre Royal, Glasgow"], ''The Times'', 17 May 2013</ref> The company is co-producing ''The Mikado'' with Scottish Opera on tour in May to July 2016, directed by [[Martin Lloyd-Evans]] and starring Suart, Sharatt, [[Andrew Shore]], [[Rebecca de Pont Davies]] and Rebecca Bottone.<ref>[https://www.scottishopera.org.uk/our-operas/15-16/the-mikado ''The Mikado''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160429065732/https://www.scottishopera.org.uk/our-operas/15-16/the-mikado |date=29 April 2016 }}, Scottish Opera, accessed March 22, 2016</ref><ref>Hall, George. [https://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/2016/the-mikado-review-at-theatre-royal-glasgow "''The Mikado'' review at Theatre Royal, Glasgow – 'visually resplendent'"], ''The Stage'', 6 May 2016</ref>
==Principal performers== [[File:George Grossmith as Bunthorne, Patience, 1881.jpg|right|thumb|upright|[[George Grossmith]] as Bunthorne in ''[[Patience (opera)|Patience]]'']]Gilbert and Sullivan aficionados frequently use the names of the principal comedians of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company to refer to time periods of the company's history.<ref name=Wilsonpassim>Wilson and Lloyd, ''passim''</ref> Thus, after the sudden death of Sullivan's brother Fred, who had created the role of the Learned Judge in ''[[Trial by Jury]]'' in 1875, the unknown [[George Grossmith]] was recruited in 1877. Before Grossmith left the company in 1889, he created the principal comic roles in nine of the operas, and so the principal comedian parts in the operas are often referred to as the "Grossmith" roles.<ref name=Wilsonpassim/> Other performers who created a long series of roles in the original productions of the operas included [[baritone]] [[Rutland Barrington]], [[mezzo-soprano]] [[Jessie Bond]], [[soprano]] [[Leonora Braham]], [[contralto]] [[Rosina Brandram]], [[tenor]] [[Durward Lely]] and [[bass-baritone]] [[Richard Temple (opera singer)|Richard Temple]]. In the original New York City productions and British touring productions, soprano [[Geraldine Ulmar]], baritone [[Signor Brocolini]], comic [[George Thorne (actor)|George Thorne]] and bass-baritone [[Fred Billington]] became particularly well known.<ref>Wilson and Lloyd, pp. 19–46</ref>
[[File:Passmore as Grand Duke Rudolph 1896.jpg|left|thumb|upright|[[Walter Passmore|Passmore]] as Rudolph in ''[[The Grand Duke]]'']] After Grossmith left the company, the most notable players of his roles during the rest of Gilbert's lifetime were [[Walter Passmore]] (principal comedian from 1894 to 1903) and [[Charles H. Workman]], who played the roles on tour with the company from 1897 and took over as principal comedian at the Savoy between 1906 and 1909.<ref>Wilson and Lloyd, pp. 59–87</ref> Both of these performers made recordings of songs from the [[Savoy operas]]. During the Passmore era, principal players of the company included Brandram and Barrington, as well as tenor [[Robert Evett]], soprano [[Isabel Jay]], sopranos [[Ruth Vincent]] and [[Florence St. John]], tenor [[Courtice Pounds]] and his sister, mezzo-soprano [[Louie Pounds]]. During Workman's tenure, principal players included contralto [[Louie René]], soprano [[Clara Dow]], [[Leo Sheffield]], and a young [[Henry Lytton]]. No complete recordings of the operas were made that included active members of the Company until the 1920s. Workman and W. S. Gilbert quarrelled over their production of ''[[Fallen Fairies]]'' in 1909, and Gilbert banned Workman from appearing in his works in Britain. It is likely that, otherwise, Workman would have continued as principal comedian of the company.<ref>Murray, Roderick. "A review of ''Lytton – Gilbert and Sullivan's Jester'' by Brian Jones" in ''The Gaiety'' (Summer, 2006)</ref> Indeed, [[Rupert D'Oyly Carte]] wrote to Workman in 1919 asking him to return to the company as principal comedian, but Workman declined.<ref>Howarth, Paul. [http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/other_gilbert/fallen_fairies/cast.html ''Fallen Fairies'' cast information] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091001175342/http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/other_gilbert/fallen_fairies/cast.html |date=1 October 2009 }} at The Gilbert and Sullivan Archive, 19 March 2005, accessed 4 November 2009</ref>
From 1909 to 1934, the principal comedian was Henry Lytton, who had been playing a variety of roles with the company steadily since 1887. He received a knighthood for his performances during his long tenure with the company.<ref>Wilson and Lloyd, p. 125</ref> Lytton's voice deteriorated during his later career, and when HMV embarked on a series of complete recordings of the operas after World War I, Lytton was not invited to record most of his roles. Instead, the concert singer [[George Baker (record singer)|George Baker]] was brought in to substitute. Other performers from this period include mezzo-soprano [[Nellie Briercliffe]], bass-baritone [[Darrell Fancourt]], who is estimated to have portrayed the Mikado of Japan more than 3,000 times, contralto [[Bertha Lewis]], tenor [[Derek Oldham]], soprano [[Elsie Griffin]] and baritones Leo Sheffield and [[Sydney Granville]].<ref>Wilson and Lloyd, pp. 90–112</ref>
[[File:Henry Lytton In An Advertisement for The Emerald Isle in The Sketch April 24 1901.png|thumb|right|upright|[[Henry Lytton]], 1901]] Lytton was succeeded in 1934 by [[Martyn Green]], who played the principal comic parts until 1951, except for a gap from the end of 1939 to 1946, when [[Grahame Clifford]] replaced him. Green's time with the company is remembered for the early Decca recordings of the operas. During Green's tenure, in addition to the long-serving Fancourt, principal players included baritone [[Richard Walker (singer)|Richard Walker]], soprano [[Helen Roberts]], mezzo-soprano [[Marjorie Eyre]], baritone [[Leslie Rands]] and contralto [[Ella Halman]]. Green was followed by [[Peter Pratt]]. He left the company in 1959, after more than eight years as principal comedian, still only 36 years old. During Pratt's years, principals included bass-baritone [[Donald Adams]], tenor [[Leonard Osborn]] (who later directed the productions), contralto [[Ann Drummond-Grant]] and mezzo-soprano [[Joyce Wright]].<ref>Rollins and Witts, pp. 176–83</ref>
Pratt's successor was [[John Reed (actor)|John Reed]], who served as principal comedian for two decades.<ref name=Wilson178/> Other stars from this era were [[Thomas Round]], [[Donald Adams]], [[Gillian Knight]], [[Valerie Masterson]] and [[Kenneth Sandford]], all of whom, except the last, left the company for the wider operatic stage of [[Royal Opera House|Covent Garden]], [[Sadler's Wells Theatre|Sadler's Wells]], [[English National Opera]], [[Aix-en-Provence Festival|Aix-en-Provence]] and elsewhere.<ref>Joseph (1994), pp. 311–43</ref> When Reed left the company in 1979, his understudy [[James Conroy-Ward]] took over until the closure of the company in 1982.<ref>Wilson and Lloyd, p. 213</ref>
From 1988, the revived company used guest artists for each production. The most regularly seen principal comedians were Eric Roberts and Richard Suart, both of whom regularly perform the "Grossmith" roles for other opera companies.<ref>Jacobs, Arthur. "D'Oyly Carte", ''The Musical Times'', September 1988, p. 471</ref> Others have included [[Sam Kelly]], [[Jasper Carrott]] and Simon Butteriss.<ref>[http://www.doylycarte.org.uk/News/Recent_Reviews.htm "Reviews"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090426095805/http://doylycarte.org.uk/News/Recent_Reviews.htm |date=26 April 2009 }}, D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, accessed 6 June 2010</ref>
==References in popular culture== In 1948, [[Flanders and Swann]] wrote a song called "In the D'Oyly Cart", a satire of the company and the rote "business" and gestures that it was accused of repeating. The song was first performed in the revue ''Oranges and Lemons'' (1948) and revived in ''Penny Plain'' (1951). It was broadcast in 1974 and included as the first track on the 1975 Flanders and Swann album, ''And Then We Wrote''.<ref>Shepherd, Marc. [http://www.cris.com/~oakapple/gasdisc/mdflaswa.htm "Flanders & Swann's "In the D'Oyly Cart" (1974)"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081226031747/http://www.cris.com/~oakapple/gasdisc/mdflaswa.htm |date=26 December 2008 }}. ''A Gilbert and Sullivan Discography'' (1999)</ref>
A one-act parody, called ''A "G. & S." Cocktail; or, A Mixed Savoy Grill'', written by Lauri Wylie, with music by [[Herman Finck]], premiered on 9 March 1925 at the [[London Hippodrome]] as part of the [[revue]] ''Better Days''. It was also broadcast by the BBC. It concerned a nightmare experienced by a D'Oyly Carte tenor.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110721000230/http://www.arcadee.freeserve.co.uk/pl121.htm Photo of libretto], David B. Lovell, bookseller</ref><ref>[http://openlibrary.org/b/OL20833472M Listing for ''A "G. & S." Cocktail''] at Open Library</ref> The company is mentioned in the 1937 musical ''[[I'd Rather Be Right]]'', with a score by [[Rodgers & Hart]] and a book by [[George S. Kaufman]] and [[Moss Hart]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=QX77o6bhB9QC&pg=PA22 ''I'd Rather Be Right''], Libretto, p. 22 {{ISBN|1-4179-9228-X}}</ref>
The 1999 film ''[[Topsy-Turvy]]'', directed by [[Mike Leigh]], depicts Richard D'Oyly Carte, Gilbert and Sullivan, as well as many members of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company in events leading up to and through the composition and production of ''The Mikado''. The film was ranked on ''[[Empire magazine]]''{{'}}s 2008 list of the 500 greatest movies of all time.<ref>[http://www.empireonline.com/500/4.asp "The 500 Greatest Movies of All Time"], ''Empire magazine'', November 2008, accessed 12 May 2013</ref>
A children's theatre company in London is called [[Theatre for Early Years#History|"Oily Cart"]], a play on the name of the company.<ref>[http://www.healthypages.co.uk/newsitem.php?news=4517 "Theatre reaches out to autistic children"]{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, HealthyPages, 2003</ref>

{{Infobox company | name = David Roytman Inc. | logo = David Roytman Luxury Judaica Logo.png | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | industry = [[Manufacturing]], [[Fashion design]] | founded = 2015 | founder = David Roytman | hq_location_city = New York | hq_location_country = US | products = [[Luxury goods|Luxury]] [[Judaica]] | owner = David Roytman | num_employees = >100 | website = https://davidroytman.com/ }} [[File:Crocodile Kippah.png|thumb|right|$1,500 crocodile leather [[kippah]]]] '''David Roytman Luxury Judaica''' is a [[manufacturing company]] established in 2015, specializing in [[Luxury goods|luxury]] [[Judaica]].
Production specializes Judaica such as [[kippah]]s, [[mezuzah]] cases, [[ketubah]] cases, and [[bag]]s for a [[tallit]] and [[tefillin]] set. Also such [[fashion accessories]] as [[cufflinks]], [[Belt (clothing)|belts]] and [[pendants]] engraved with Jewish symbols. The company also designs individual [[monograms]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://davidroytman.com/loyalty-program/ |title=Loyalty program |date=2016-12-06 |access-date=November 24, 2018}}</ref>
While the company is incorporated in New York, design and manufacturing take place in [[Odessa, Ukraine]]. The company has [[outlet stores]] in major cities around the world, like Jerusalem, London, Moscow, New York, Odessa, Paris, St. Petersburg, Vienna and Vilnius.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://davidroytman.com/locations/ |title=Store locations |date=2016-10-31 |access-date=November 24, 2018}}</ref>
Kippahs and other products are made from such exotic materials as [[crocodile]] leather, [[ostrich leather]], [[python skin]] and [[stingray]] leather.<ref name="about">{{Cite web |url=https://davidroytman.com/about |title=About us |date=2016-10-31 |access-date=November 24, 2018}}</ref> [[Laser engraving]] is used to apply the [[company logo]],<ref name="about"/><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.if24.ru/david-rojtman-kipu-vyrezaem-lazerom/ |title=Давид Ройтман: "Кипу мы вырезаем лазером" |lang=ru |date=2017-03-31 |access-date=November 24, 2018}}</ref> which is based on the initials of its Odessa-born [[Israelis|Israeli]] owner, David Roytman. A David Roytman Luxury Judaica kippah can cost over $,1000.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5013849,00.html |title=Jerusalem Judaica store offers exotic animal-hide kippot |work=[[Ynet]] |publisher=Yedioth Internet |date=2017-09-08 |access-date=November 24, 2018}}</ref>
Famous people owning David Roytman Luxury Judaica kippas are United States President [[Donald Trump]], Israeli Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] and Ukainian Prime Minister [[Vladimir Groisman]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://finance.rambler.ru/economics/37217345-david-roytman-kak-postroit-monopolnyy-biznes-na-lyuksovoy-iudaike-i-prodavat-kipy-za-1-5-tys/?updated |title=Как построить монопольный бизнес на люксовой иудаике (и продавать кипы за $1,5 тыс.) |lang=ru |access-date=November 24, 2018}}</ref>
In 2018 the company installed a {{Convert|2|m}} high mezuzah, claimed to be the tallest mezuzah in the world, made of [[LED screen]]s, on the roof of the [[Aish HaTorah]] [[yeshiva]] building in the [[Old City of Jerusalem]], as a [[publicity stunt]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5390034,00.html |title=The world's largest musical mezuzah |work=[[Ynet]] |publisher=Yedioth Internet |date=2018-11-06 |access-date=November 24, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://news.jeps.ru/novosti/luxury-judaica-samaya-bolshaya-mezuza-v-mire-ustanovlena-v-ierusalime.html |title=Самая большая в мире мезуза установлена на крыше Иерусалима |publisher=Jewish Community of S. Petersburg |lang=ru |date=2018-11-01 |access-date=November 24, 2018}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox song | name = Hells Bells | cover = HellsBells.jpg | alt = | border = yes | caption = Artwork for one of the continental European releases | type = single | artist = [[AC/DC]] | album = [[Back in Black]] | B-side = What Do You Do for Money Honey | released = 31 October 1980 | format = [[7" single|7 inch]] | recorded = Spring 1980 at [[Compass Point Studios]] in [[The Bahamas]] | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Hard rock]]{{cite book|first= Ahmet |last= Ertegün |authorlink= Ahmet Ertegün |title= 'What'd I Say?': The Atlantic Story: 50 Years of Music |year= 2001 |publisher= Welcome Rain Publisher |quote= ''Back in Black'' includes one of their best known songs, 'You Shook Me All Night Long' (#35 Pop), and hard rock classics 'Hells Bells', 'Back in Black' (#37 Pop) and 'Rock and Roll Ain't Noise Pollution'. |page= 546 |isbn= 978-1-56649-048-1}} | length = 5:12 | label = [[Atlantic Records]] | writer = {{hlist|[[Angus Young]]|[[Malcolm Young]]|[[Brian Johnson]]}} | producer = [[Robert John "Mutt" Lange]] | prev_title = [[You Shook Me All Night Long]] | prev_year = 1980 | next_title = [[Back in Black (song)|Back in Black]] | next_year = 1980 | misc = {{Audio sample | type = single | file = Hells Bells by AC DC.ogg}} {{External music video|{{YouTube|etAIpkdhU9Q|"Hells Bells"}}}} }} "'''Hells Bells'''" is the first track of ''[[Back in Black]]'', the seventh studio album by Australian [[hard rock]] band [[AC/DC]] and their comeback album after the death of lead singer [[Bon Scott]]. "Hells Bells" is the second single from ''Back in Black'', released on 31 October 1980. The song also appears on ''[[Who Made Who]]'', AC/DC's 1986 soundtrack to the [[Stephen King]] movie ''[[Maximum Overdrive]]'' and on both versions of 1992's ''[[AC/DC Live]]''. ==Composition== The song begins with a [[bell (instrument)|bell]] slowly tolling four times, after which [[Angus Young]] starts playing the song's main riff. [[Malcolm Young]] then joins in, followed by [[Phil Rudd]] on drums and [[Cliff Williams]] on bass. The bell tolls a total of 13 times during the song's introduction. A {{convert|2,000|lb|adj=on}} cast bronze bell, made by [[John Taylor & Co|John Taylor Bellfounders]] in [[Loughborough]], [[Leicestershire]], was used on the track. It is a replica of the Denison Bell in the Carillon Tower at the Loughborough War Museum. The band first attempted to record the actual Denison Bell, but that proved problematic due to disruptions by [[pigeon]]s nesting in the tower. The AC/DC logo and the words "Hell's Bell" are engraved on the replica.{{cite news|title= Loughborough Carillon > Issue No. 13 |newspaper= Carillon Chimes |location= Leicestershire, England |date= November 2011 |url= https://sites.google.com/site/loughboroughcarillon/gui-information |accessdate= 19 January 2015}} ==Personnel== * [[Brian Johnson]] – lead vocals * [[Angus Young]] – lead guitar * [[Malcolm Young]] – rhythm guitar, backing vocals * [[Cliff Williams]] – bass guitar, backing vocals * [[Phil Rudd]] – drums ==Charts and certifications== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ===Charts=== {|class="wikitable sortable" !Year !Chart !Peak
position |- |1980 |France ([[Institut français d'opinion publique|IFOP]]){{cite web|title= Le Détail par Artiste |publisher= InfoDisc |id= Select "AC/DC" from the artist drop-down menu |accessdate= 20 May 2016 |url= http://www.infodisc.fr/Tubes_Artistes_A.php |language= fr}} |align="center"|16 |- |rowspan="2"|1981 {{singlechart|Germany2|25|artist=AC/DC|song=Hells Bells|id=9353|accessdate=5 June 2014}} |- |US ''Billboard'' [[Mainstream Rock (chart)|Top Tracks]]{{cite web|title= Back in Black – Awards |publisher= [[AllMusic]]. [[All Media Network]] |accessdate= 5 June 2014 |url= http://www.allmusic.com/album/back-in-black-mw0000188862/awards}} |align="center"|50 |- |rowspan="3"|2012 {{singlechart|Austria|43|artist=AC/DC|song=Hells Bells|accessdate=5 June 2014}} |- {{singlechart|France|43|artist=AC/DC|song=Hells Bells|accessdate=5 June 2014}} |- |US ''Billboard'' [[Digital Songs|Hot Digital Songs]] |align="center"|51 |} {{col-2}} ===Certifications=== {{Certification Table Top}} !scope="col" colspan="3"|Ringtones |- {{Certification Table Entry|region=Canada|type=single|artist=AC/DC|title=Hells Bells|award=Gold|certyear=2007|salesamount=20,000|digital=true}} {{Certification Table Entry|region=United States|type=single|artist=AC/DC|title=Hell's Bells|award=Gold|certyear=2007|digital=true}} {{Certification Table Bottom|nounspecified=true}} {{col-end}} ==In baseball== The song was used as the [[entrance music]] for former [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB) player [[Trevor Hoffman]] at [[home (sports)|home]] games from 1998 to 2010, thrilling the crowd as he emerged.{{cite news|first= Joe |last= Capozzi |title= Hell's Bells — Trevor Hoffman, who started his career with Florida Marlins, bound for Hall after retirement |newspaper= [[The Palm Beach Post]] |date= 11 January 2011 |quote= I'll never forget games I've covered at Petco Park when Hoffman trotted in from the bullpen to pitch the ninth inning to the ear-shattering sounds of AC/DC's Hell's Bells—perhaps some of the loudest, most electrifying crowd noise I've ever heard. |accessdate= 28 January 2011 |archivedate= 26 January 2011 |archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/5w2ENdOuD?url=http://blogs.palmbeachpost.com/marlins/2011/01/11/hells-bells-trevor-hoffman-who-started-his-career-with-florida-marlins-bound-for-hall-after-retirement/ |deadurl= no |url= http://marlins.blog.palmbeachpost.com/2011/01/11/hells-bells-trevor-hoffman-who-started-his-career-with-florida-marlins-bound-for-hall-after-retirement/}}{{cite news|first= Bill |last= Center |title= Story of Hells Bells anthem, etc. |newspaper= [[U-T San Diego]] |date= 26 September 2006 |accessdate= 26 September 2006 |url= http://legacy.utsandiego.com/uniontrib/20060926/news_lz1x26hoffrnt.html}} The [[San Diego Padres]]' usage of "Hells Bells" for Hoffman was a forerunner in the [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]] theme songs for [[Closer (baseball)|closer]]s used throughout MLB stadiums.{{cite magazine|first= Daniel |last= Engber |title= Hear My Song, Fear My Fastball |magazine= [[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |date= 14 April 2006 |quote= The closer songs of the early '90s tended to mix a cranky bravado with the threat of mental instability—don't mess with me, I'm so mean and crazy. |archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/5w2FqzHcz?url=http://www.slate.com/id/2139937/ |archivedate= 26 January 2011 |deadurl= yes |accessdate= 28 January 2011 |url= http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/mixing_desk/2006/04/hear_my_song_fear_my_fastball.html}}{{cite news|first= Anthony |last= Tarantino |title= For whom the bell tolls |newspaper= [[U-T San Diego]] |date= 19 April 2004 |quote= Since using the idea, the Padres have become a forerunner in the closer-theme explosion. |archivedate= 28 January 2011 |accessdate= 28 January 2011 |archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/5w4QAOc1m?url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20040419/news_lz1s19majmo.html |deadurl= yes |url= http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20040419/news_lz1s19majmo.html}} The ''[[San Jose Mercury News]]'' and [[ESPN.com]] wrote that the song should be honored by the [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum]].{{cite news|first= Kaitee |last= Daly |title= John Fogerty's 'Centerfield' sparks a list |page= 2 |publisher= [[ESPN.com]] |date= 28 July 2010 |archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/5xKnky6W6?url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=daley%2F100728_hall_of_fame_songs |archivedate= 20 March 2011 |deadurl= yes |accessdate= 5 June 2014 |url= http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=daley/100728_hall_of_fame_songs}}{{cite news|first= Gary |last= Peterson |title= Peterson: Baseball Hall of Fame should honor AC/DC |newspaper= [[San Jose Mercury News]] |page= C-2 |date= 19 March 2011 |url= https://www.mercurynews.com/2011/03/19/peterson-baseball-hall-of-fame-should-honor-acdc/ |accessdate= 5 June 2014}} At Hoffman's [[Number (sports)#Retired numbers|number retirement]] ceremony, Brian Johnson paid tribute in a video to Hoffman for "rocking the mound".{{cite news|first= Dan |last= Hayes |title= PADRES NOTES: Hoffman ceremony filled with surprises |newspaper= U-T San Diego |date= 21 August 2011 |archivedate= 22 August 2011 |deadurl= no |accessdate= 5 June 2014 |archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/618fupqBw?url=http://www.nctimes.com/sports/baseball/professional/mlb/padres/article_71dd6fe1-bd1f-526c-9f47-1684a4661232.html |url= http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2011/Aug/21/padres-notes-hoffman-ceremony-filled-with/}}{{cite news|first= Tim |last= Sullivan |title= Grand gesture is prime Trevor Time for good reason |newspaper= U-T San Diego |date= 21 August 2011 |archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/618h4HTMz?url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2011/aug/21/grand-gesture-prime-trevor-time-good-reason/ |archivedate= 22 August 2011 |deadurl= no |accessdate= 5 June 2014 |url= http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2011/aug/21/grand-gesture-prime-trevor-time-good-reason/}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{AC/DC singles}}
