page.title: List of National Treasures of Japan (ancient documents)

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta5) ([[User:FA RotBot|FA RotBot]])
revision.text: [[File:Enchin ordination document.jpg|thumb|upright=1.4|right|alt=Text in Chinese script on lined paper with red stamp marks|Part of the ordination certificate of [[Enchin]] from 833]] The term "[[National Treasures of Japan|National Treasure]]" has been used in Japan to denote [[Cultural Properties of Japan|cultural properties]] since 1897.{{cite book |last= Coaldrake |first= William Howard |title= Architecture and authority in Japan |url= https://books.google.com/?id=bCLNX8_a4WQC&pg=PA248&dq=Law+for+the+Preservation+of+Ancient+Shrines+and+Temples |origyear= 1996 |year= 2002 |publisher= Routledge |location= London, New York |isbn= 0-415-05754-X |page= 248 }}{{Harvnb|Enders|Gutschow|1998|p=12}} The definition and the criteria have changed since the introduction of the term. These ancient documents adhere to the current definition, and have been designated National Treasures since the Law for the Protection of Cultural Properties came into effect on June 9, 1951. The items are selected by the [[Agency for Cultural Affairs]], a special body of the [[Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (Japan)|Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology]], based on their "especially high historical or artistic value".{{cite web |title = Cultural Properties for Future Generations |url = http://www.bunka.go.jp/tokei_hakusho_shuppan/shuppanbutsu/bunkazai_pamphlet/pdf/pamphlet_en_03_ver05.pdf |publisher = [[Agency for Cultural Affairs]], Cultural Properties Department |location = Tokyo, Japan |format = PDF |date = March 2017 |accessdate = 2017-12-17 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171216231044/http://www.bunka.go.jp/tokei_hakusho_shuppan/shuppanbutsu/bunkazai_pamphlet/pdf/pamphlet_en_03_ver05.pdf |archivedate = 2017-12-16 |df = |deadurl = yes }} "Ancient documents" is one of thirteen categories of National Treasures recognized by the agency. The list presents 62 documents or sets of documents from classical to early modern Japan, from the [[Asuka period]] to the [[Meiji period]]. The actual number of items is more than 62 because groups of related objects have been combined into single entries. The list contains items of various type such as letters, diaries, records or catalogues, certificates, imperial decrees, testaments and maps. The documents record early Japanese government and Buddhism including early Japanese contact with China, the organization of the state and life at the Japanese imperial court. They are housed in 14 Japanese cities in [[Buddhist temple|temples]] (35), museums (13), libraries or archives (6), [[Shinto shrine|shrines]] (4), universities (2) and in private collections (2). Most entries (28) in the list are located in [[Kyoto]]. The documents in this list were made predominantly with a writing brush on paper and, in many cases, present important examples of [[calligraphy]].{{cite web | publisher = [[Agency for Cultural Affairs]] | script-title=ja:国指定文化財 データベース |trans-title=Database of National Cultural Properties | accessdate = 2009-04-16 | date = 2008-11-01 | url = http://www.bunka.go.jp/bsys/index.asp | language = Japanese }} Writing was physically introduced to Japan from China in the form of inscribed artefacts at the beginning of the Christian era. Examples, some of which have been designated as [[List of National Treasures of Japan (archaeological materials)|archaeological National Treasures]], include coins of the reign of [[Wang Mang]] (AD 8–25), a 1st-century gold seal from Shikanoshima, a late 2nd century iron [[Tōdaijiyama Sword|sword from the Tōdaijiyama burial mound]], the [[Seven-Branched Sword]] with inscription from 369 and a large number of bronze mirrors—the oldest dating to the 3rd century.{{Harvnb|Seeley|1991|p=10}}{{Harvnb|Seeley|1991|p=11}} All of these artefacts originated on the continent, most likely in China. However, the written inscriptions on them may not have been recognized as writing but instead may have been mistaken for decorations by the Japanese. When the Japanese later manufactured locally copies of original Chinese mirrors, they may have continued to believe the written inscriptions to be merely decorative.{{Harvnb|Seeley|1991|p=12}}{{Harvnb|Seeley|1991|p=13}} The concept of writing came to Japan from the Korean kingdom of [[Baekje]] in the form of classical Chinese books likely written on paper and in the form of manuscript rolls (''kansubon'').{{Harvnb|Seeley|1991|p=9}} This probably happened at the beginning of the 5th century (around 400), and certainly during the 6th century.{{Harvnb|Seeley|1991|p=6}}{{cite web | url = http://www.t-net.ne.jp/~keally/hist.html | title = Historic Archaeological Periods in Japan| first = Charles T. | last = Keally | date = 2009-06-14 | work = Japanese Archaeology | publisher = Charles T. Keally | accessdate = 2010-09-09 }} According to legend the scholar [[Wani (scholar)|Wani]] introduced the Chinese writing system as well as [[Confucianism]] to Japan. The oldest texts of Japanese origin, which show a clear understanding of the concept of writing, date to the 5th century and are—like most texts from before 700—inscriptions on stone or metal.{{Harvnb|Seeley|1991|p=16}} Examples include three archaeological National Treasures: [[Suda Hachiman Shrine Mirror]] from about the 5th century, which is a poor copy of a Chinese original, the [[Inariyama Sword]] from 471 or 531 and the Eta Funayama burial mound sword from about the 5th century.{{Harvnb|Seeley|1991|p=17}}{{Harvnb|Seeley|1991|p=24}} The abrupt transition from an unfamiliarity with writing to reading and writing complicated works in a foreign language required the earliest Japanese texts be composed and read by people from the continent such as Wani. The Inariyama Sword is also the oldest example of [[man'yōgana]] use, a [[writing system]] that employs [[Chinese character]]s to represent the [[Japanese language]].{{Harvnb|Seeley|1991|p=23}} Soon after the introduction of writing, scribes were appointed to the provinces to "record events and report conditions".{{Harvnb|Seeley|1991|p=8}}{{Harvnb|Sakamoto|1991|p=3}} While writing in Japan was limited during the 5th and 6th centuries, the number of documents written locally increased in the 7th century; though most of them have been lost.{{Harvnb|Seeley|1991|p=40}} By the end of the 7th century increased cultural dependence on China caused reading and writing, particularly in government and religion, to become an integral part of Japanese life. There were two major factors for this development: starting with the [[Taika Reforms]] (645–649) and continuing with the [[Asuka Kiyomihara Code]] (689) and censuses from 670 and 690, a Chinese style centralised state was formed, requiring the need for a large number of officials who were literate and educated in, among others, Confucian texts at the ''Daigakuryo'' ("University") founded under [[Emperor Tenchi]]. The second factor was the increasing popularity of Buddhism, which had been introduced to Japan in the mid-6th century and strongly promoted by [[Prince Shōtoku]] (574–622). The [[Sangyō Gisho]] ("Annotated Commentaries on the Three Sutras"), traditionally attributed to Prince Shōtoku, is the oldest extant Japanese text of any length.{{Harvnb|Seeley|1991|p=41}} Buddhism required the study of sutras written in Chinese and the state founded a Sutra Copying Bureau (''shakyōjo'') before 727.Probably much before this date. The oldest Japanese books are two chronicles, [[Kojiki]] and [[Nihon Shoki]], from the early 8th century. While the [[man'yōgana|phonogram orthography]] enjoyed increasing popularity during the 8th century, it was not yet used for longer prose. The modern [[kana]], notably [[hiragana]] and [[katakana]] were developed in the [[Heian period]].{{Harvnb|Seeley|1991|p=55}} ==Statistics== Almost half of all entries in the list are located in [[Kyoto]]. [[File:National Treasures of Japan (ancient documents).png|right|thumb|300px|alt=Most of the National Treasures are found in the Kansai area and north-east Honshū.|Map showing the location of ancient document National Treasures in Japan]] {| class="wikitable" style="width:35%; text-align:center; background:#fff; float:left;" |- ! style="text-align:center; background:#ffdead;"| Prefecture ! style="text-align:center; background:#ffdead;"| City ! style="text-align:center; background:#ffdead;"| National Treasures |- | style="background:#efefef;" | [[Chiba Prefecture|Chiba]] | style="background:#efefef;" | [[Sakura, Chiba|Sakura]] | style="background:#efefef;" | 2 |- | [[Fukuoka Prefecture|Fukuoka]] | [[Fukuoka, Fukuoka|Fukuoka]] | 1 |- | style="background:#efefef;" | [[Gifu Prefecture|Gifu]] | style="background:#efefef;" | [[Motosu, Gifu|Motosu]] | style="background:#efefef;" | 1 |- | rowspan="2"| [[Kyoto Prefecture|Kyoto]] | [[Kyoto, Kyoto|Kyoto]] | 28 |- | [[Miyazu, Kyoto|Miyazu]] | 1 |- | style="background:#efefef;" | [[Nara Prefecture|Nara]] | style="background:#efefef;" | [[Nara, Nara|Nara]] | style="background:#efefef;" | 4 |- | rowspan="2"| [[Osaka Prefecture|Osaka]] | [[Kawachinagano, Osaka|Kawachinagano]] | 1 |- | [[Shimamoto, Osaka|Shimamoto]] | 1 |- | style="background:#efefef;" rowspan="2" | [[Shiga Prefecture|Shiga]] | style="background:#efefef;" | [[Nagahama, Shiga|Nagahama]] | style="background:#efefef;" | 1 |- | style="background:#efefef;" | [[Ōtsu, Shiga|Ōtsu]] | style="background:#efefef;" | 8 |- | [[Shizuoka Prefecture|Shizuoka]] | [[Makinohara, Shizuoka|Makinohara]] | 1 |- | style="background:#efefef;" | [[Tochigi Prefecture|Tochigi]] | style="background:#efefef;" | [[Ōtawara, Tochigi|Ōtawara]] | style="background:#efefef;" | 1 |- | [[Tokyo Prefecture|Tokyo]] | [[Tokyo, Tokyo|Tokyo]] | 10 |- | style="background:#efefef;" | [[Wakayama Prefecture|Wakayama]] | style="background:#efefef;" | [[Kōya, Wakayama|Kōya]] | style="background:#efefef;" | 1 |- | [[Yamagata Prefecture|Yamagata]] | [[Yonezawa, Yamagata|Yonezawa]] | 1 |} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; background:#fff; float:left;" |- ! style="text-align:left; background:#ffdead;"| PeriodOnly the oldest period is counted, if a National Treasure consists of items from more than one period. ! style="text-align:left; background:#ffdead;"| National Treasures |- | [[Asuka period]] | 1 |- | [[Nara period]] | 8 |- | [[Heian period]] | 32 |- | [[Tang Dynasty]] | 1 |- | [[Kamakura period]] | 17 |- | [[Yuan Dynasty]] | 1 |- | [[Nanboku-chō period]] | 1 |- | [[Momoyama period]] | 1 |} {{Clear}} ==Usage== The table's columns (except for ''Content'' and ''Images'') are sortable pressing the arrows symbols. The following gives an overview of what is included in the table and how the sorting works. *''Name'': the name as registered in the Database of National Cultural Properties *''Author'': name of the author(s) *''Content'': information about the type of document and its content *''Date'': period and year; The column entries sort by year. If only a period is known, they sort by the start year of that period. *''Format'': principal type, technique and dimensions; The column entries sort by the main type: ''scroll'' (includes handscrolls and letters), ''collection'' (sets of items) and ''other'' (includes textiles, hanging scrolls, stone inscriptions and folding books 帖) *''Present location'': "building-name temple/museum/shrine-name town-name prefecture-name"; The column entries sort as "prefecture-name town-name". *''Image'': picture of the document or of a characteristic document in a group of documents ==Treasures== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%; background:#fff;" |- ! style="text-align:left; background:#ffdead;" scope="col"| Name ! style="text-align:left; background:#ffdead;" scope="col"| Authors ! style="text-align:left; background:#ffdead;" class="unsortable" scope="col"| Content ! style="text-align:left; background:#ffdead;" scope="col"| Date ! style="text-align:left; background:#ffdead;" scope="col"| Format ! style="text-align:left; background:#ffdead;" scope="col"| Present location ! style="text-align:left; background:#ffdead;" class="unsortable" scope="col"| Image |- | {{nihongo|Documents of the Shimazu Family|島津家文書|Shimazu-ke Monjo}}{{cite journal |title = The University of Tokyo Library System Bulletin Vol 42, No 4 |publisher = [[Tokyo University]] library |accessdate = 2010-01-03 |date = September 2003 |format = PDF |url = http://www.lib.u-tokyo.ac.jp/koho/kanpo/vol42/vol42-4.pdf |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110605102330/http://www.lib.u-tokyo.ac.jp/koho/kanpo/vol42/vol42-4.pdf |archivedate = 2011-06-05 |df = }}33 document boxes are attached to the nomination. | {{center|—}} | Large scale collection of documents of the [[Shimazu clan]] covering among others politics, diplomacy, social economy and inheritance | 0794[[Heian period]] to [[Meiji period]] | {{sort|various|bundle/batch. The total number of documents is 15,133 (848 rolled scrolls, 752 bound books, 2629 bound {{nihongo|double-leaved|袋とじ|fukuro-toji}} books, 2 hanging scrolls, 4908 single sheet letters, 160 maps of glued sheets, 207 single sheet maps)}} | Tokyo Tokyo Historiographical Institute of the University of Tokyo[[Historiographical Institute of the University of Tokyo]], [[Tokyo]] | [[File:Shimazuke monjo.jpg|150px|alt=Text in Chinese script which is partially faded.]] |- | {{nihongo|Genealogy of the Amabe Clan|海部氏系図|amabeshi keizu}}{{cite web |title = Special Exhibition – The Sacred World of Shinto Art in Kyoto, Images from the Exhibit, Section II Shinto History and Section III Festivals in Kyoto |publisher = [[Kyoto National Museum]] |accessdate = 2009-04-30 |url = http://www.kyohaku.go.jp/eng/tokubetsu/shoukai/kaifu.htm |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080607031541/http://www.kyohaku.go.jp/eng/tokubetsu/shoukai/kaifu.htm |archivedate = 2008-06-07 |df = }}{{cite web | script-title=ja:海部氏系図 | language = Japanese |trans-title=Genealogy of the Amabe Clan | publisher = Kono Shrine | accessdate = 2010-01-03 | url = http://www.motoise.jp/main/houmotu/keizu1.html }}A survey document (海部氏勘注系図) of one rolled scroll is attached to the nomination. | {{center|—}} | Oldest extant Japanese family tree | 0794[[Heian period]] | {{sort|rolled scroll|one rolled scroll, {{convert|25.7|x|228.5|cm|abbr=on}}}} | Kyoto Miyazu Kono Shrineprivate, [[Kono Shrine]], [[Miyazu, Kyoto|Miyazu]], [[Kyoto Prefecture|Kyoto]] | [[File:Amabe Clan genealogy.jpg|150px|alt=Very few vertical lines in Chinese characters on yellow aged paper.]] |- | {{nihongo|Letter from the viceroy of Portuguese India|ポルトガル国印度副王信書|porutogaru kokuindo fukuō shinsho}}{{cite book | title = A Carta do Vice-Rei D. Duarte de Menezes a Toyotomi Hideyoshi, 1588. |trans-title=Letter from the viceroy D. Duarte de Menezes to Toyotomi Hideyoshi, 1588. | series = Colecção Fundação Cidade de Lisboa | publisher = [[Open Library]] | accessdate = 2009-04-28 | language = Portuguese | url = http://openlibrary.org/b/OL16789820M/Carta-do-Vice-Rei-D.-Duarte-de-Menezes-a-Toyotomi-Hideyoshi%2C-1588. }}{{cite book |last1=Commission for the protection of cultural properties |last2=Mainichi Shimbun |authorlink2=Mainichi Shimbun |last3=National Treasure Commission|script-title=ja:原色版国宝: 桃山・江戶・明治 |trans-title=National Treasures in tricolor prints: Momoyama, Edo and Meiji periods |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8nMYAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=2010-09-05|series=National Treasures in tricolor prints, Commission for the protection of cultural properties |volume=12 |year= 1968|page=136 |publisher=[[Mainichi Shimbun]] |language=Japanese|title=原色版国宝: 上古・飛鳥・奈良 }} | [[Duarte de Menezes]] | Letter from [[Duarte de Menezes]], viceroy of [[Portuguese India]] to ''[[daimyō]]'' [[Toyotomi Hideyoshi]] concerning the suppression of Christians in Japan | 1588-04[[Azuchi–Momoyama period]], April 1588 | {{sort|letter|one single sheet letter, ink on paper, {{convert|60.8|x|76.4|cm|abbr=on}}}} | Kyoto Kyoto Myohoin{{nihongo|[[Myōhō-in]]|妙法院}}, [[Kyoto]] | [[File:Letter_from_the_viceroy_of_Portuguese_India.gif|150px|alt=Handwritten document with a wide ornamental border on the left/right and top side. A seal is attached to the bottom of the document via a cord.]] |- | {{nihongo||越中国官倉納穀交替記残巻|etchū kuni kansō nōkoku kōtaiki zankan}}{{cite web |script-title = ja:越中国官倉納穀交替記残巻 |title = etchū kuni kansō nōkoku kōtaiki zankan |publisher = Ōtsu City Museum of History |language = Japanese |accessdate = 2009-04-28 |url = http://www.rekihaku.otsu.shiga.jp/bunka/data/bz_359.html |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110722124423/http://www.rekihaku.otsu.shiga.jp/bunka/data/bz_359.html |archivedate = 2011-07-22 |df = }}{{cite book | last = Akihiro | first = Watanabe | title = Fudokoku in the Heian Period | journal = Shigaku zasshi | volume = 98 | issue = 12 | pages = 1891–1937 | publisher = The Historical Society of Japan | date = 1989-12-20 | url = http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110002369240/ | issn = 0018-2478 | accessdate = 2010-01-03}} | {{center|—}} | Agricultural records of villages in the {{nihongo|Tonami District|礪波郡}} of [[Etchū Province]]. It is a valuable resource for the study of an area under the [[Ritsuryō]] law in the 8th to 10th century. | 0751[[Nara period]] and [[Heian Period]], 751–901 | {{sort|rolled scroll|one rolled scroll}} | Shiga Otsu Ishiyamadera[[Ishiyama-dera]], [[Ōtsu, Shiga|Ōtsu]], [[Shiga Prefecture|Shiga]] | {{center|—}} |- | {{nihongo|Sugaura documents|菅浦文書|sugaura monjo}} and {{nihongo|Illustrated map of Sugaura and Ōura Shimo manors|菅浦与大浦下庄堺絵図|sugaura to ōura shimo no shō sakai ezu}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bunka.go.jp/koho_hodo_oshirase/hodohappyo/__icsFiles/afieldfile/2018/03/09/a1402236_01_1.pdf|script-title=国宝・重要文化財（美術工芸品）の指定について～|language=Japanese|trans-title=Designation of National Treasures and Important Cultural Properties in the arts and crafts category|author=|date=2018-03-09|website=|publisher=[[Agency for Cultural Affairs]]|access-date=2018-03-10|quote=|title=Archived copy|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180310010751/http://www.bunka.go.jp/koho_hodo_oshirase/hodohappyo/__icsFiles/afieldfile/2018/03/09/a1402236_01_1.pdf|archive-date=2018-03-10|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite conference |url=http://publications.nichibun.ac.jp/region/d/NSH/series/symp/2009-12-15/s001/s037/pdf/article.pdf |title=Space in Shinto Shrines and Its Visual Representation from the Thirteenth through the Fifteenth Centuries |last1=Simonova-Gudzenko |first1=Ekaterina |date=2015-11-13 |publisher=International Research Center for Japanese Studies |book-title=Interpretations of Japanese Culture : Views from Russia and Japan |pages= |location= |conference=International Symposium in Russia 2007 |id= }} | {{center|—}} | Documents of the history of Sugaura that are relevant for the study of the history of {{nihongo3||惣|sō}}, autonomous peasant communities in medieval Japan. The ''[[shōen]]'' map contains the boundaries of Sugaura and Ōura-shimo manors whose boundaries were contested at the time, but more prominently [[Chikubu Island]] in [[Lake Biwa]] with a [[Buddhist temples in Japan|temple]]-[[Shinto shrine|shrine]] complex ([[Jingū-ji]]). | 1302[[Kamakura period]] 1302 (map); Kamakura period – [[Edo period]] (documents) | {{sort|various|65 bound {{nihongo|double-leaved|袋とじ|fukuro-toji}} books, 1 hanging scroll}} | Shiga Nagahama Nishiazai Suga Shrine[[Suga Shrine (Nagahama)|Suga Shrine]], [[Nishiazai, Shiga|Nishiazai]], [[Nagahama, Shiga|Nagahama]], [[Shiga Prefecture|Shiga]] | [[File:Sugaura monjo.jpg|150px|alt=Japanese calligraphic writing.]] [[File:Sugaura to ōura shimo no shō sakai ezu.jpg|150px|alt=Illustrated three-dimensional map showing an island and part of a shore line.]] |- | {{nihongo|Documents related to the priest Enchin|円珍関係文書|enchin kankei monjo}}{{cite web | last = Tokyo National Museum | title = Letter (Documents related to the priest Enchin). | publisher = [[Tokyo National Museum]] | accessdate = 2009-04-28 | url = http://www.tnm.go.jp/en/servlet/Con?colid=B2405.2&pageId=E15&processId=00&ref=&Q1=&Q2=&Q3=&Q4=&Q5=&F1=&F2= }}{{cite web |last = The Agency for Cultural Affairs |script-title = ja:円珍関係文書 文化遺産オンライン |trans-title = Documents related to the priest Enchin, cultural heritage online |publisher = [[Tokyo National Museum]] |accessdate = 2009-04-28 |language = Japanese |url = http://bunka.nii.ac.jp/SearchDetail.do?heritageId=77126&imageNum=5 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = page.title: List of artworks in the collection of the Royal Society of Chemistry

revision.comment: /* Corpus */{{lang}}: promote ISO 639-2, -3 codes to equivalent ISO 639-1 codes;
revision.text:
This is a list of surviving [[Ancient Rome|ancient Roman]] [[gold glass]] portraits of the finer painted sort. The majority of surviving Roman gold glass pieces are the cut-off bottoms of drinking glasses made with unpainted [[gold leaf]]. These sometimes bear the names of individuals and were probably commemorative gifts on a special occasion such as a wedding anniversary or winning a contest. Achieving a good likeness was probably not an aim, and certainly not an achievement of this class of object,{{cn|date=April 2018}} and they are not included here. The objects here belong to a smaller class of finely painted portrait miniatures, although a few seem also to have been originally placed in cups. Following a table summarizing the basic information, individual portraits are discussed in separate sections. ==Corpus== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Portrait ! Location ! Date ! Size ! Inscription |- | [[File:Galla Placidia (rechts) und ihre Kinder.jpg|250px]] | [[Museo di Santa Giulia]], [[Brescia]], [[Italy]]{{cite web|title=Masterpieces. Desiderius' Cross|url=http://www.bresciamusei.com/nsantagiulia.asp?nm=14&t=Masterpieces%2E+Desiderius%27+Cross|website=Fondazione Brescia Musei|accessdate=4 December 2015}} See section below for full account. | 3rd century | 6 cm in diameter{{cite web|last1=Burns|first1=Jasper|title=The Brescia Medallion - Who, When, and Where?|url=http://www.jasperburns.com/gasbresc.html|accessdate=4 December 2015}} | Greek: {{lang|grc|ΒΟΥΝΝΕΡΙ ΚΕΡΑΜΙ}}Breck 1927, p. 353
(meaning uncertain) |- | [[File:Medallion with a Portrait of Gennadios MET DP325825 (cropped).jpg|250px]] | [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], [[New York City]]{{cite web|title=Medallion with a Portrait of Gennadios|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search/466645|publisher=[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]|accessdate=4 December 2015}} | 250–300 | 4.1 cm in diameter | Greek: {{lang|grc|ΓΕΝΝΑΔΙ ΧΡΩΜΑΤΙ ΠΑΜΜΟΥΣΙ}}Weitzmann 1979, p. 287
("Gennadios, most skilled in music")Evans 2001, p. 9 |- | [[File:Ficoroni medallion.jpg|250px]] | Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York City{{cite web|title=Gold Glass Medallion with a Mother and Child|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search/463989?=&imgno=1&tabname=object-information|publisher=[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]|accessdate=4 December 2015}} | early 4th century | 4.8 cm in diameter | no inscription |- | [[File:Gold-glass portrait of a woman (Corning Museum of Glass).png|250px]] | [[Corning Museum of Glass]], [[Corning (city), New York|Corning, New York]]{{cite web|title=Medallion with Portrait|url=http://www.cmog.org/artwork/medallion-portrait|publisher=[[Corning Museum of Glass]]|accessdate=4 December 2015}} | 3rd century | 4.9 cm in diameter | Latin: {{lang|la|ANATOLI GAVDIAS}}
("Anatolius, rejoice!") |- | [[File:Gold-glass portrait of a man (Victoria and Albert Museum).jpg|250px]] | [[Victoria and Albert Museum]], [[London]]{{cite web|title=Medallion (museum number: 1052-1868)|url=https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O119621/medallion-unknown/|publisher=[[Victoria and Albert Museum]]|accessdate=5 December 2015}} | 3rd or 4th century | 4.4 cm in diameter | no inscription |- | [[File:Gold-glass portrait of a man (British Museum).jpg|250px]] | [[British Museum]], London{{cite web|title=disc / bowl (Museum number: 1890,0901.1)|url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=443950&partId=1&searchText=gold-glass&images=true&page=6|publisher=[[British Museum]]|accessdate=4 December 2015}} | ? | 5.1 cm in diameter | no inscription |- | [[File:Gold-glass portrait of two young men (Bologna).jpg|250px]] | [[The Archeological Civic Museum (MCA) of Bologna|Archeological Museum]], [[Bologna]], [[Italy]]{{cite web|author1=Egisto Sani|title=Golden Glass - II|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/69716881@N02/10873947723/in/photostream/|publisher=[[flickr]]|accessdate=7 December 2015}} | 1st quarter of 4th century | 5.1 cm in diameterDucati 1929, pp. 236–240 | Latin transcription of Greek: {{lang|la|PIE ZESES}}
("Drink and you will live") |- | [[File:Gold-glass portrait of a young man (Bologna).jpg|250px]] | Archeological Museum, Bologna, Italy{{cite web|author1=Egisto Sani|title=Golden Glass|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/69716881@N02/10871138703/|publisher=[[flickr]]|accessdate=7 December 2015}} | 1st quarter of 4th century | 4.5 cm in diameterDucati 1929, p. 236 | no inscription |- | [[File:Gold-glass portrait of Onesimus.jpg|250px]] | Archeological Museum, Bologna, ItalyDucati 1929, pp. 233–235 | 4th century{{cite web|title=Emilia Romagna - BOLOGNA: MUSEO CIVICO ARCHEOLOGICO|url=http://www.gianlucacarboni.it/articolo.asp?pagina=988|accessdate=8 December 2015|quote=Sezione romana: vetri dorati (IV sec.d.C.)}} | 3.5 cm in diameter | Latin: {{lang|la|M. COCCEIUS ONESIMUS}}
(probably, the name of the boy) |- | [[File:Arezzo medallion.jpg|250px]] | Archeological Museum, [[Arezzo]], ItalyLapatin 2015, p. 89 pl. 59, p. 237 | 200–250 | 4.4 cm in diameter | no inscription |- | [[File:Gold-glass portrait of husband and wife (Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana, Museo Sacro, Inv. no. 743).jpg|250px]] | [[Museo Sacro]], [[Vatican Library]]Metropolitan Museum of Art 1982, p. 98 | first half of the 3rd century | 4.9 cm in diameter | Latin: {{lang|la|GRECO RIBIBETPROPINATUIS}}
(perhaps, "Gregory, drink and drink to thine") |- | [[File:Gold-glass family portrait (Vatican Library) 1.jpg|250px]] | Vatican Library{{cite web|author1=Andrew Simsky |title=Christian gold-glasses from the Vatican museum |url=http://asimsky.livejournal.com/7005.html |accessdate=4 December 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160427184414/http://asimsky.livejournal.com/7005.html |archivedate=27 April 2016 |df= }} | ? | ? | no inscription |- | [[File:Eusebius medallion 1.jpg|250px]] | Museo Sacro, Vatican Library | 3rd century{{cite web|title=Vetro dorato con ritratto virile|url=http://www.ilsole24ore.com/fc?cmd=art&codid=20.0.1837121990&chId=30&artType=Articolo_foto-gallery&DocRulesView=Libero&id=4&top=-480|website=ilsole24ore.com|accessdate=5 December 2015}} | 4.8 cm in diameterLapatin 2015, p. 87 pl. 57 | Latin: {{lang|la|EUSEBI ANIMA DULCIS}}
(?) |- | [[File:Gold-glass portrait of husband and wife (Musei Vaticani, inv. 60639).jpg|250px]] | Vatican MuseumsLega 2012, p. 276 + p. 277 fig. 7a,b | 3rd or 4th centuryLega 2012, p. 263 | ? | Latin: {{lang|la|GREGORI SIMPLICI CONRECESCATES}}
(?) |- | [[File:Gold-glass portrait of a man (San Panfilo catacomb) colour.jpg|250px]] | [[Catacombs of Rome|Catacomb]] of San Panfilo, [[Rome]]Whitehouse 1996, pp. 10–11 | 4th century or earlier | ? | no inscription |- | [[File:Gold-glass portrait of a woman (Turin).jpg|250px]] | [[Turin City Museum of Ancient Art|Museo Civico]], [[Turin]], Italy{{cite web|title=ritrato femminile (Marcia Otacilia Severa?)|url=http://www.palazzomadamatorino.it/it/le-collezioni/catalogo-delle-opere-online/ritrato-femminile-marcia-otacilia-severa|website=Palazzo Madama|accessdate=7 December 2015}} | mid-3rd century | 4.5 cm in diameter | no inscription |- | [[File:Gold-glass portrait of a man (Turin).jpg|250px]] | Museo Civico, Turin, Italy[[:File:Arte tardoromana, medaglione con figura femminile del II sec e con figura maschile del II-III sec.JPG|Arte tardoromana, medaglione con figura femminile del II sec e con figura maschile del II-III sec.JPG]] shows the two Turin medallions together | 3rd century | ? | no inscription |- | [[File:Late-17th-century copy of a lost gold-glass portrait (Reserve Collection of the Vatican Museum) mirrored.jpg|250px]] | Vatican MuseumsHowells 2010, pp. 97–98 | 17th-century copy of a lost original | ? | Latin: [partly illegible] {{lang|la|CE PIE ZESES}}Vaiani 2014, p. 244Garrucci 1795, pl. XLI p. 1, p. 84
("Drink and you will live") |} ==Brescia medallion== [[File:Galla Placidia (rechts) und ihre Kinder.jpg|thumb|right|Brescia medallion]] The portrait medallion is a part of the ornamentation of the so-called Desiderius Cross, 9th-century [[processional cross|processional]] [[crux gemmata]] currently preserved in [[Museo di Santa Giulia]], [[Brescia]], [[Italy]]. The medallion is often referred to as a portrait of [[Galla Placidia]] and her children, but the scholarly consensus is strongly against this 18th-century identification. Some 19th-century scholars, including [[Raffaele Garrucci]] and [[Hermann Vopel]], suspected the work to be a fake.Garrucci 1858, p. 83; pl. XL, 7Vopel 1899, no. 507 The earliest mention of the medallion comes from a 17th-century inventory. In 1762, [[Francesco Antonio Zaccaria]] recalled that he saw it circa 1725. Several details indicate the [[Egypt (Roman province)|Egyptian]], perhaps [[Alexandria]]n origin of the medallion. Both words of the inscription ({{lang|grc|ΒΟΥΝΝΕΡΙ ΚΕΡΑΜΙ}}) end in [[iota]], possibly indicating the [[Ancient Greek]] dialect of Egypt; {{lang|grc|ΚΕΡΑΜΙ}}, then, means "potter". Stylistically, the painting is closely related to the 3rd-century [[Fayum mummy portraits|mummy portraits]] found in the [[Faiyum Oasis]]. The costumes are more consistent with the contemporary fashions in Egypt than in Rome itself. In particular, the mantle worn by the middle figure is not fastened by a [[fibula]], but instead knotted; one parallel for this is a 3rd-century [[Copts|Coptic]] [[tapestry]] medallion, now in the [[Hermitage Museum]], showing the goddess [[Gaia (mythology)|Gea]] with her mantle knotted in a similar way.Breck 1927, p. 354 The peculiar hair style of the older woman is unknown in Roman portraiture, but can be found on some 3rd-century plaster mummy masks from Egypt.One example from the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]: [https://www.flickr.com/photos/mharrsch/599898584 link]. Daniel T. Howells (2015) summarizes the research into the Brescia medallion demonstrating its connection to contemporaneous Roman-Egyptian art (in particular the Fayum mummy portraits) as well as linguistic evidence proving the authenticity of the artefact versus the now dubious claim about it being a forgery.Daniel Thomas Howells (2015). "[https://www.britishmuseum.org/pdf/Late_Antique_Gold_Glass_online.pdf A Catalogue of the Late Antique Gold Glass in the British Museum (PDF).]" London: the British Museum (Arts and Humanities Research Council). Accessed 2 October 2016, p. 7: "''Other important contributions to scholarship included the publication of an extensive summary of gold glass scholarship under the entry ‘Fonds de coupes’ in Fernand Cabrol and Henri Leclercq’s comprehensive Dictionnaire d’archéologie chrétienne et de liturgie in 1923. Leclercq updated Vopel’s catalogue, recording 512 gold glasses considered to be genuine, and developed a typological series consisting of eleven iconographic subjects: biblical subjects; Christ and the saints; various legends; inscriptions; pagan deities; secular subjects; male portraits; female portraits; portraits of couples and families; animals; and Jewish symbols. In a 1926 article devoted to the brushed technique gold glass known as the Brescia medallion (Pl. 1), Fernand de Mély challenged the deeply ingrained opinion of Garrucci and Vopel that all examples of brushed technique gold glass were in fact forgeries. The following year, de Mély’s hypothesis was supported and further elaborated upon in two articles by different scholars. A case for the Brescia medallion’s authenticity was argued for, not on the basis of its iconographic and orthographic similarity with pieces from Rome (a key reason for Garrucci’s dismissal), but instead for its close similarity to the Fayoum mummy portraits from Egypt. Indeed, this comparison was given further credence by Walter Crum’s assertion that the Greek inscription on the medallion was written in the Alexandrian dialect of Egypt. De Mély noted that the medallion and its inscription had been reported as early as 1725, far too early for the idiosyncrasies of Graeco-Egyptian word endings to have been understood by forgers.''" "''Comparing the iconography of the Brescia medallion with other more closely dated objects from Egypt, Hayford Peirce then proposed that brushed technique medallions were produced in the early 3rd century, whilst de Mély himself advocated a more general 3rd-century date. With the authenticity of the medallion more firmly established, Joseph Breck was prepared to propose a late 3rd to early 4th century date for all of the brushed technique cobalt blue-backed portrait medallions, some of which also had Greek inscriptions in the Alexandrian dialect. Although considered genuine by the majority of scholars by this point, the unequivocal authenticity of these glasses was not fully established until 1941 when Gerhart Ladner discovered and published a photograph of one such medallion still in situ, where it remains to this day, impressed into the plaster sealing in an individual loculus in the Catacomb of Panfilo in Rome (Pl. 2). Shortly after in 1942, Morey used the phrase ‘brushed technique’ to categorize this gold glass type, the iconography being produced through a series of small incisions undertaken with a gem cutter’s precision and lending themselves to a chiaroscuro-like effect similar to that of a fine steel engraving simulating brush strokes.''" Jás Elsner (2007) also contends that the Brescia medallion likely depicts a family from [[Alexandria]], since the inscription is in the Alexandrian dialect of Greek, and provides possible dates ranging from the early-3rd to mid-5th century AD, before it found its way to Italy where it adorned a 7th-century cross.Jás Elsner (2007). "The Changing Nature of Roman Art and the Art Historical Problem of Style," in Eva R. Hoffman (ed), ''Late Antique and Medieval Art of the Medieval World'', 11-18. Oxford, Malden & Carlton: Blackwell Publishing. {{ISBN|978-1-4051-2071-5}}, p. 17, Figure 1.3 on p. 18. {{Gallery |width=200 |height=200 |File:Croce di Desiderio (Santa Giulia, Brescia) fronte.JPG |Desiderius cross (enlarge the image to see the medallion in the centre of the lower part of the cross) |File:Brescia medallion - inscription.jpg |Greek inscription, {{nowrap|{{lang|grc|ΒΟΥΝΝΕΡΙ ΚΕΡΑΜΙ}}}}. |File:Brescia medallion - middle figure.jpg |The middle figure, mantle knotted on her breast. |File:Coptic textile with representation of Gaia-Isis in a medallion (Egypt. 4th century AD, 25 cm diam) Hermitage.jpg |Coptic tapestry medallion showing [[Gaia (mythology)|Gea]] wearing a mantle knotted on her breast. From [[Akhmim]], 3rd or 4th century. [[Hermitage Museum]].{{cite web|title=The immortal Alexander the Great|url=http://www.hermitage.nl/en/pers/alexander_de_grote/beeldmateriaal.htm|website=Hermitage Amsterdam|accessdate=10 December 2015}}{{cite web|title=Воображаемый музей|url=http://vittasim.livejournal.com/55588.html|accessdate=10 December 2015}} |File:Aelia Galla Placidia.jpg |The right figure, with a hair style peculiar to Egypt.}} ==Ficoroni medallion== [[File:Ficoroni medallion.jpg|thumb|right|Ficoroni medallion]] ==Fakes== Gold-glass forgeries are known to have been forged all through the 18th and 19th centuries. In 1759, French [[antiquarian]] [[Anne Claude de Caylus]] wrote that contemporary Roman dealers were selling gold-glass reproductions to tourists who thought them original.Caylus 1759, p. 195, quote: "Ce moyen a été retrouvé à Rome, il y a très-peu d'années; j'en ai jugé par quelques morceaux très- bien traités: on s'en est servi pour tromper les Etrangers; mais celui qui possédoit ce petit secret est mort sans le publier"Breck 1927, pp. 353–354 [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] has what are thought to be two 18th-century fake group portraits, while the [[British Museum]] has two 19th-century ones. {{Gallery |width=250 |height=250 |File:Fake gold-glass portrait (Metropolitan Museum of Art 17.190.108).jpg |18th century
Metropolitan Museum of Art{{cite web|title=Medallion with Family Portrait (accession number: 17.190.108)|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search/463988|publisher=[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]|accessdate=8 December 2015}} |File:Fake gold-glass portrait (Metropolitan Museum of Art 17.190.107).jpg |18th century
Metropolitan Museum of Art{{cite web|title=Medallion with Double Portrait (accession number: 17.190.107)|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search/463987|publisher=[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]|accessdate=8 December 2015}} |File:Fake gold-glass portrait (British Museum 1847,0824.2).jpg |19th century
British Museum{{cite web|title=forgery / medallion (museum number: 1847,0824.2)|url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=3448813&partId=1&people=125148&peoA=125148-3-17&view=list&page=1|publisher=[[British Museum]]|accessdate=8 December 2015}} |File:Fake gold-glass portrait (British Museum OA.10900).jpg |19th century
British Museum{{cite web|title=forgery / medallion (museum number: OA.10900)|url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=3448834&partId=1|publisher=[[British Museum]]|accessdate=8 December 2015}} }} ==See also== * [[Gold glass]] * [[Roman portraiture]] * [[Fayum mummy portraits]] ==Notes== {{reflist|20em}} ==References== * {{cite journal|author1=[[Joseph Breck (curator)|Joseph Breck]]|title=The Ficoroni Medallion and Some Other Gilded Glasses in the Metropolitan Museum of Art|journal=[[The Art Bulletin]]|date=1927|volume=9|issue=4|pages=352–356|doi=10.2307/3046553|jstor=3046553}} * {{cite book|author1=[[Anne Claude de Caylus]]|title=Recueil d'antiquités égyptiennes, étrusques, grecques et romaines|date=1795|publisher=Desant & Saillant|volume=III}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=rC8CAAAAYAAJ google books preview] * [[Pericle Ducati]]{{sup|[[:it:Pericle Ducati|(it)]]}} (1929). ''[http://www.inasa-roma.it/pdf/P_DUCATI_I_vetri_dorati_romani_nel_Museo_Civico_di_Bologna.pdf I vetri dorati romani nel Museo Civico di Bologna]''. * Elsner, Jás (2007). "The Changing Nature of Roman Art and the Art Historical Problem of Style," in Eva R. Hoffman (ed), ''Late Antique and Medieval Art of the Medieval World'', 11-18. Oxford, Malden & Carlton: Blackwell Publishing. {{ISBN|978-1-4051-2071-5}}. * {{cite book|author1=Helen C. Evans|author2=Melanie Holcomb|author3=Robert Hallman|title=The Arts of Byzantium|date=2001|publisher=[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]|location=[[New York City]]|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/research/metpublications/The_Arts_of_Byzantium_The_Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art_Bulletin_v_58_no_4_Spring_2001}} * {{cite book|author1=[[Raffaele Garrucci]]|title=Vetri ornati di figure in oro: trovati nei cimiteri dei cristiani primitivi di Roma|date=1858|publisher=Tipografia Salviucci}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=voJCAAAAcAAJ google books preview] * Howells, Daniel Thomas (2010). ''[http://sro.sussex.ac.uk/6351/1/Howells,_Daniel_Thomas.pdf Late Antique Gold Glass in the British Museum]'', PhD Thesis. * Howells, Daniel Thomas (2015). "[https://www.britishmuseum.org/pdf/Late_Antique_Gold_Glass_online.pdf A Catalogue of the Late Antique Gold Glass in the British Museum (PDF).]" London: the British Museum (Arts and Humanities Research Council). Accessed 2 October 2016. * {{cite book|author1=Kenneth Lapatin|title=Luxus: The Sumptuous Arts of Greece and Rome|date=2015|publisher=Getty Publications|isbn=9781606064221}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=n5T1CAAAQBAJ google books preview] * {{cite journal|author1=Claudia Lega|title=Il corredo epigrafico dei vetri dorati: novità e considerazioni|journal=Sylloge epigraphica Barcinonensis|date=2012|volume=10|pages=263–286|url=http://www.raco.cat/index.php/SEBarc/article/view/263971/351470}} * Metropolitan Museum of Art (1982). ''[http://www.metmuseum.org/research/metpublications/The_Vatican_Collections_The_Papacy_and_Art The Vatican Collections: The Papacy and Art]''. {{ISBN|0-87099-321-6}}. * {{cite journal|author1=Elena Vaiani|title="Clues to the ancient world": le piccole antichità nel Museo Cartaceo, con una verifica sulla collezione di Flavio Chigi|journal=Studi di Memofonte|date=2014|url=http://www.memofonte.it/home/files/pdf/XII_2014_VAIANI.pdf|accessdate=8 December 2015}} * {{cite book|author1=Hermann Vopel|title=Die altchristlichen Goldgläser|date=1899|url=https://archive.org/details/diealtchristlic00vopegoog|accessdate=10 December 2015}} * {{cite book|title=Age of Spirituality: Late Antique and Early Christian Art, Third to Seventh Century|editor=[[Kurt Weitzmann]]|date=1979|publisher=[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]|location=[[New York City|New York]]|isbn=9780870991790|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/research/metpublications/Age_of_Spirituality_Late_Antique_and_Early_Christian_Art_Third_to_Seventh_Century}} * {{cite journal|author1=[[David Whitehouse]]|title=Glass, Gold, and Gold-Glasses|journal=Expedition|date=1996|volume=38|issue=2|pages=4–12|url=http://www.penn.museum/sites/expedition/glass-gold-and-gold-glasses/}} ==External links== * {{Commons category-inline|Gold-glass portraits}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gold-glass portraits}} [[Category:Lists of works of art]] [[Category:Ancient Roman glassware]] [[Category:Ancient Roman art]] [[Category:Glass works of art]] [[Category:Miniature painting]]

page.title: Lviv Theatre of Opera and Ballet

revision.text:
{{Feminism sidebar}} In [[feminist theory]], the '''male gaze''' is the act of depicting women and the world, in the [[visual arts]] and [[literature]], from a masculine, heterosexual perspective that presents and represents women as [[Sexual objectification|sexual objects]] for the pleasure of the male viewer.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Eaton|first=E.W.|title=Feminist philosophy of art|journal= Philosophy Compass | volume = 3 | issue = 5 | pages = 873–893 | publisher = [[Wiley-Blackwell|Wiley]] | doi = 10.1111/j.1747-9991.2008.00154.x | date = September 2008 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1747-9991.2008.00154.x | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/feminism-aesthetics/|title=Feminist Aesthetics|work=[[Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy]]|quote=Assumes a standard point of view that is masculine and heterosexual. [...] The phrase 'male gaze' refers to the frequent framing of objects of visual art so that the viewer is situated in a 'masculine' position of appreciation.|date=Winter 2012|accessdate=May 13, 2015}}</ref><ref>That it applies to literature and the visual arts: Łuczyńska-Hołdys, Małgorzata (2013). ''Soft-Shed Kisses: Re-visioning the Femme Fatale in English Poetry of the 19th Century'', Cambridge Scholars Publishing, 15.</ref> The male gaze has three perspectives: (i) that of the person behind the camera, (ii) that of the characters within the representation, and (iii) that of the spectator.<ref>{{cite book|last=Devereaux|first=Mary|chapter=Oppressive Texts, Resisting Readers, and the Gendered Spectator: The "New" Aesthetics|editor1-last=Brand|editor1-first=Peggy Z.|editor2-last=Korsmeyer|editor2-first=Carolyn|title=Feminism and tradition in aesthetics|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=qVqJvchIb5YC&pg=PA126 126]|publisher=Penn State University Press|location=University Park, Pennsylvania|year=1995|isbn=9780271043968}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Walters|first=Suzanna Danuta|author-link=Suzanna Danuta Walters|chapter = Visual pressures: on gender and looking |editor-last=Walters|editor-first=Suzanna Danuta|title= Material girls: making sense of feminist cultural theory|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=1V5JYMY3P1QC&pg=PA57 57]|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley, California|year=1995|isbn= 9780520089778|ref=harv}}</ref>
The film critic [[Laura Mulvey]] coined the term ''male gaze'', which is contrasted with the concept of the [[female gaze]];<ref name="interview-mulvey-2011"/><ref name="jacobsson">{{Cite report |author= Jacobsson, Eva-Maria |date= 1999 |title= A Female Gaze? |url= http://cid.nada.kth.se/pdf/cid_51.pdf |format= pdf |publisher= [[Royal Institute of Technology|Royal Institute of Technology (Kungliga Tekniska Högskolan)]] |location= Stockholm, Sweden |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111004025557/http://cid.nada.kth.se/pdf/cid_51.pdf |archivedate= 2011-10-04 |df= }}</ref> as such, the male gaze is comparable to [[scopophilia]], which is sexual pleasure derived from observing the passive female as object.<ref name=mulvey1975/>{{rp|815}}
== Background == The concept of the '''male gaze''' was first developed by the feminist film critic [[Laura Mulvey]] in the essay "Visual Pleasure and Narrative Cinema" (1975), in which she proposes that an asymmetry of [[Power (social and political)|power]] between the sexes is a controlling force in cinema; and that the male gaze is constructed for the pleasure of the male viewer, which is deeply rooted in the ideologies and discourses of [[patriarchy]].<ref>{{Citation|last=Weeks|first=L. Paul|contribution=Male gaze|editor-last=Ritzer|editor-first=George|title=Encyclopedia of social theory|page=467|publisher=[[SAGE Publications|Sage]]|location=Thousand Oaks, California|year=2005|isbn=9780761926115|ref=harv|postscript = .}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=mTZ1AwAAQBAJ&pg=PT505 Preview.]</ref><ref name=mulvey1975>{{cite journal | last = Mulvey | first = Laura | author-link = Laura Mulvey | title = Visual pleasure and narrative cinema | journal = [[Screen (journal)|Screen]] | volume = 16 | issue = 3 | pages = 6–18 | publisher = [[Oxford University Press|Oxford Journals]] | doi = 10.1093/screen/16.3.6 | date = Autumn 1975 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1093/screen/16.3.6 | ref = harv | postscript = . | deadurl = no | archiveurl = http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20171030193554/https://dx.doi.org/10.1093/screen/16.3.6 | archivedate = 2017-10-30 | df = }}{{pb}} ''Also available as'': {{citation | last = Mulvey | first = Laura | author-link = Laura Mulvey | contribution = Visual pleasure and narrative cinema | editor-last = Mulvey | editor-first = Laura | editor-link = Laura Mulvey | title = Visual and other pleasures | pages = 14–30 | publisher = Palgrave Macmillan | location = Houndmills, Basingstoke, Hampshire England New York | year = 2009 | edition = 2nd | isbn = 9780230576469|ref=harv|postscript = .}} [https://www.amherst.edu/system/files/media/1021/Laura%20Mulvey,%20Visual%20Pleasure.pdf Pdf via Amherst College.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304111127/https://www.amherst.edu/system/files/media/1021/Laura%20Mulvey,%20Visual%20Pleasure.pdf |date=2016-03-04 }}</ref> Conceptually, the male gaze is a prominent element of [[feminist film theory]] and [[media studies]], and is linked to models of [[voyeurism]], [[scopophilia]], and [[narcissism]].
The perspective of the male gaze occurs when the camera places the viewer in the perspective of a heterosexual man whose sight lingers on the curves of a woman's body.<ref>{{cite web | last1 = Streeter | first1 = Thomas | last2 = Hintlian | first2 = Nicole | last3 = Chipetz | first3 = Samantha | last4 = Callender | first4 = Susanna | title = This is Not Sex: A Web Essay on the Male Gaze, Fashion Advertising, and the Pose | url = http://www.uvm.edu/~tstreete/powerpose/index.html | date = 2005 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20111106152945/http://www.uvm.edu/~tstreete/powerpose/index.html | archivedate = 2011-11-06 | df = }} Web essay about the male gaze in advertising.</ref> Usually, the male gaze displays the woman on two different levels: (i) as an erotic object for the characters in the film story, and (ii) as an erotic object for the male viewer of the film.{{Citation needed|date=February 2015}} By way of the male gaze, the man emerges as the dominant power within the film fantasy, in which the woman is a passive object for the active gaze of the male viewer. The passive-object and active-viewer pairing is basic to the patriarchal order, and is typical in the "illusionistic narrative film" of mainstream cinema, where the male gaze has precedence over the female gaze — the underlying asymmetry of social and political power, between the sexes.<ref name=mulvey1975/>{{rp|14}}<ref name="interview-mulvey-2011">{{cite journal | last = Sassatelli | first = Roberta | title = Interview with Laura Mulvey: Gender, Gaze and Technology in Film Culture | journal = [[Theory, Culture & Society]] | volume = 28 | issue = 5 | pages = 123–143 | publisher = [[Sage Publications|Sage]] | doi = 10.1177/0263276411398278 | date = September 2011 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0263276411398278 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>{{rp|127}}
This inequality can be attributed to patriarchy which has been defined as a social ideology embedded in the belief systems of Western culture and in patriarchal societies. It is either masculine individuals or institutions created by these individuals that exert the power to determine what is considered "natural".<ref name="Privileging the Male Gaze">{{cite journal | last1 = Pritchard | first1 = Annette | last2 = Morgan | first2 = Nigel J. | title = Privileging the male gaze: gendered tourism landscapes | journal = Annals of Tourism Research | volume = 27 | issue = 4 | pages = 884–905 | publisher = [[Elsevier]] | doi = 10.1016/S0160-7383(99)00113-9 | date = October 2000 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0160-7383(99)00113-9 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Over the course of time, these constructed beliefs begin to seem "natural" or "normal" because they are prevalent and carry out unchallenged, thus arguing that Western culture has adopted a dyadic, hierarchical ideology which sets masculinity in binary opposition to femininity thus creating levels of inferiority.<ref name="Privileging the Male Gaze"/>
Mulvey describes its two central forms that are based in [[Freud]]'s concept of scopophilia, as: "pleasure that is linked to sexual attraction (voyeurism in extremis) and scopophilic pleasure that is linked to narcissistic identification (the introjection of ideal egos)",<ref name=mulvey1975/> in order to demonstrate how women have historically been forced to view film through the "male gaze". It also suggests that the male gaze denies women their human identity, relegating them to the status of objects to be admired for physical appearance and male sexual desires and fantasies.
In "Visual Pleasure and Narrative Cinema", Mulvey discusses several different types of spectatorship that may occur while viewing a film. They can involve unconsciously or, in some cases, consciously engaging in the typical, ascribed societal roles of men and women.
In relation to [[phallocentrism]], films may be viewed in "three different looks"; the first refers to the camera as it records the actual events of the film, the second describes the nearly voyeuristic act of the audience as one engages in watching the film itself, and the third refers to the characters that interact with one another throughout the film. The main idea that seems to bring these actions together is that "looking" is generally seen as an active male role, while the passive role of being looked at is immediately adopted as a female characteristic. It is under the construction of patriarchy that Mulvey argues that women in film are tied to desire and that female characters hold an "appearance coded for strong visual and erotic impact". The female actor is never meant to represent a character that directly affects the outcome of a plot or keep the story line going, but is inserted into the film as a way of supporting the male role and "bearing the burden of sexual objectification" that he cannot.<ref name=mulvey1975/>
In other words, the woman is passive to the active gaze from the man and can be linked to scopophilia (or scoptophilia), which can be described as pleasure derived from looking. As an expression of [[sexuality]], scopophilia refers to [[sexual pleasure]] derived from looking at erotic objects: erotic photographs, [[pornography]], naked bodies, etc. In sum, according to Mulvey, the categories of pleasurable viewing are twofold: voyeurism, which derives pleasure from viewing a distant other, and projecting one's fantasies, usually sexual, onto that person, and narcissism, a form of recognition of one's self in the image of another we are viewing. Mulvey also believes that in order to enjoy a film as a woman, or any gender other than male, we must learn to identify with the male protagonist.<ref name=mulvey1975/> [[Wendy Arons]] adds that [[sexualization|hypersexualization]] diminishes the symbolic threat posed by violent female characters in [[action film]]s, "The focus on the body—as a body in ostentatious display of breasts, legs, and buttocks—does mitigate the threat that women pose to 'the very fabric of... society' by reassuring the (male) viewer of his [[Male privilege|privilege]] as the possessor of the objectifying gaze."<ref>{{citation | last = Arons | first = Wendy | contribution = "If her stunning beauty doesn't bring you to your knees, her deadly drop kick will": violent women in Hong Kong Kung Fu film | editor-last1 = McCaughey | editor-first1 = Martha | editor-last2 = King | editor-first2 = Neal | editor-link1 = Martha McCaughey | title = Reel knockouts: violent women in the movies | page = 41 | location = Austin, Texas | publisher = University of Texas Press | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
Mulvey's essay also states that the female gaze is the same as the male gaze. This means that women look at themselves through the eyes of men.<ref name="interview-mulvey-2011"/> The male gaze may be seen by a [[feminist]] either as a manifestation of unequal power between gazer and gazed, or as a conscious or subconscious attempt to develop that [[Gender inequality|inequality]]. From this perspective, a woman who welcomes an objectifying gaze may be simply [[conforming]] to norms established to benefit men, thereby reinforcing the power of the gaze to reduce a recipient to an object. Welcoming such objectification may be viewed as akin to [[exhibitionism]].<ref name="interview-mulvey-2011" />
The possibility of an analogous female gaze<ref>{{cite web | last = Felluga | first = Dino | title = "Modules on Lacan: on the gaze" ''Introductory guide to critical theory'' | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20050415054601/http://www.sla.purdue.edu/academic/engl/theory/psychoanalysis/lacangaze.html | archive-date = 15 April 2005 | url = http://www.sla.purdue.edu/academic/engl/theory/psychoanalysis/lacangaze.html | publisher = [[Purdue University]] | location = West Lafayette, Indiana, US | date = April 2005 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite report |author= Jacobsson, Eva-Maria |date= 1999 |title= A female gaze? |url= http://cid.nada.kth.se/pdf/cid_51.pdf |format= pdf |publisher= [[Royal Institute of Technology|Royal Institute of Technology (Kungliga Tekniska Högskolan)]] |location= Stockholm, Sweden |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111004025557/http://cid.nada.kth.se/pdf/cid_51.pdf |archivedate= 2011-10-04 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last = Paul | first = Nalini | title = Other ways of looking: the female gaze in Jean Rhys' ''Wide Sargasso Sea'' | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090127060053/http://www.sharp.arts.gla.ac.uk/issue2/paul.htm | archive-date = 27 January 2009 | url = http://www.sharp.arts.gla.ac.uk/issue2/paul.htm | journal = ESharp (journal run by postgraduates for postgraduates) | volume = 2 | publisher = [[University of Glasgow]] | date = Spring 2004 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = Kelly | first = Eileen | title = The female gaze | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20030201090344/http://www.salon.com/mwt/feature/2003/01/30/gaze/index_np.html | archive-date = 1 February 2003 | url = http://www.salon.com/mwt/feature/2003/01/30/gaze/index_np.html | work = [[Salon (website)|Salon]] | publisher = Salon Media Group | date = 30 January 2003}}</ref> may arise from considering the male gaze. Mulvey argues that "the male figure cannot bear the burden of sexual objectification. Man is reluctant to gaze". Describing ''[[Wide Sargasso Sea]]'' (1966), by [[Jean Rhys]], [[Nalini Paul]] indicates that the Antoinette character gazes at Rochester, placing a [[garland]] upon him, making him appear heroic: "Rochester does not feel comfortable with having this role enforced upon him; thus, he rejects it by removing the garland, and crushing the flowers."<ref name="interview-mulvey-2011" />
From the male perspective, a man possesses the gaze because he is a man, whereas a woman has the gaze only when she assumes the male gazer role—when she objectifies others by gazing at them like a man. [[Eva-Maria Jacobsson]] supports Paul's description of the "female gaze" as "a mere cross-identification with masculinity", yet evidence of women's objectification of men—the discrete existence of a ''female gaze''—can be found in the "boy toy" ads published in [[teen magazines]], for example, despite Mulvey's contention that ''the gaze'' is ''property'' of one gender. Whether or not this is an example of female gaze or rather an internalized male gaze is up for debate, along with the other ideas on this subject. In terms of power relationships, the gazer can direct a gaze upon members of the same gender for [[asexuality|asexual]] reasons, such as comparing the gazer's [[body image]] and clothing to those of the gazed-at individual.<ref name="interview-mulvey-2011" />{{rp|127}}
With respect to her essay, Mulvey stressed in a 2011 interview with [[Roberta Sassatelli]]: "First, that the 1975 article "Visual Pleasure and Narrative Cinema" was written as a [[polemic]], and as [[Mandy Merck]] has described it, as a manifesto; so I had no interest in modifying the argument. Clearly I think, in retrospect from a more nuanced perspective, about the inescapability of the male gaze."<ref name="interview-mulvey-2011" />{{rp|128}}
== Criticizing the male gaze ==
===Matrixial gaze=== [[Bracha Ettinger]] criticizes this notion of the male gaze by her proposition of a ''[[Matrixial Gaze|matrixial gaze]]''.<ref>{{cite book | last = Ettinger | first = Bracha | author-link = Bracha Ettinger | title = The matrixial gaze | publisher = Feminist Arts and Histories Network, Department of Fine Art, University of Leeds | location = Leeds, UK | year = 1995 | isbn = 9780952489900 }}</ref> The matrixial gaze is not operative where a "male gaze" is placed opposite to a "female gaze" and where both positive entities constitute each other from a lack (such an umbrella concept of the gaze would precisely be what scholars such as [[Slavoj Žižek]] claim is the [[Lacan]]ian definition of "The Gaze"). Ettinger's proposal doesn't concern a subject and its object, existing or lacking. Rather, it concerns "trans-subjectivity" and shareability on a partial level, and it is based on her claim concerning a feminine-matrixial difference that escapes the phallic opposition of masculine/feminine and is produced in a process of co-emergence. Ettinger works from the very late Lacan, yet, from the angle she brings, it is the structure of the Lacanian subject itself that is deconstructed to a certain extent, and another kind of feminine dimension appears, with its hybrid and floating matrixial gaze.<ref>{{citation | last = Ettinger | first = Bracha | author-link = Bracha Ettinger | contribution = The with-in-visible screen | editor-last = de Zegher | editor-first = M. Catherine | title = Inside the visible: an elliptical traverse of 20th century art in, of, and from the feminine | pages = 89–116 | publisher = [[MIT Press]] | location = Cambridge, Massachusetts | year = 1996 | isbn = 9780262540810 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
===''Ways of Seeing'': the Renaissance nude=== In the book ''[[Ways of Seeing]]'' (1972), John Berger addressed the subject of female [[sexual objectification]] in the arts, noting that "according to usage and conventions, which are at last being questioned, but have by no means been overcome — men act and women appear. Men look at women. Women watch themselves being looked at."<ref>{{citation | last = Berger | first = John | author-link = John Berger | contribution = Section 3 | editor-last = Berger | editor-first = John | editor-link = John Berger | title = Ways of seeing | pages = 45, 47 | publisher = [[BBC]] Penguin Books | location = London | year = 1973 | isbn = 9780563122449 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Such [[mores|usages and conventions]] of observation relate the [[objectification|objectifying]] male gaze to Lacan's theory of the [[social alienation]] that results from the psychological split, between seeing one's self and seeing the ideal of one's self. In [[Italian Renaissance painting]], especially in the genre of the nude subject, that perceptual split arises from being both the viewer and the viewed, and from seeing one's self through the [[gaze]] of other people.<ref>{{citation | last1 = Sturken | first1 = Marita | last2 = Cartwright | first2 = Lisa | contribution = Spectatorship, Power, and Knowledge | editor-last1 = Sturken | editor-first1 = Marita | editor-last2 = Cartwright | editor-first2 = Lisa | title = Practices of Looking: An Introduction to Visual Culture | page = 81 | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = Oxford New York | year = 2001 | isbn = 9780198742715 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
===Women and the gaze=== [[Griselda Pollock]], in her article, "Modernity and the Spaces of Femininity" argues that the female gaze can often be visually negated.<ref name="Pollock-pp50-90">{{citation | last = Pollock | first = Griselda | author-link = Griselda Pollock | contribution = Modernity and the spaces for femininity | editor-last = Pollock | editor-first = Griselda | editor-link = Griselda Pollock | title = Vision and difference: femininity, feminism, and histories of art | pages = 50–90 | publisher = Routledge | location = London New York | year = 1988 | isbn = 9780415007214 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} * ''Abridged version available at'': {{citation | last = Pollock | first = Griselda | author-link = Griselda Pollock | contribution = Modernity and the spaces for femininity | editor-last1 = Broude | editor-first1 = Norma | editor-last2 = Garrard | editor-first2 = Mary D. | title = The expanding discourse: feminism and art history | pages = 245–267 | publisher = Icon Editions | location = New York, New York | year = 1992 | isbn = 9780064302074 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [https://loomen.carnet.hr/pluginfile.php/214673/mod_resource/content/0/griseldapollockMOdernityandSpacesofFemininity.pdf Pdf.]</ref> Pollock claims [[Robert Doisneau]]'s photo ''[[Sidelong Glance]]'' supports this argument.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Vidani|first1=Peter|title=a collection on feminism and design: photograph: Robert Doisneau, ''Sidelong Glance'' (1948))|url=http://gorillagirls.tumblr.com/post/99484635013/robert-doisneau-sidelong-glance-1948-in-the|website=gorillagirls.tumblr.com|publisher=[[Gorilla Girls]]|accessdate=23 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160130094020/http://gorillagirls.tumblr.com/post/99484635013/robert-doisneau-sidelong-glance-1948-in-the|archivedate=30 January 2016|df=}}</ref> In the photo, a middle-aged [[bourgeois]] couple are looking around an art gallery. The spectator view of the picture is from inside the shop but the couple are looking in different places than the view of the spectator. The woman is commenting on an image to her husband, while the husband is being distracted by a nude female painting. The nude female painting is hung within view of the spectator. The woman is looking at another image, but it is out of view of the spectator. The man's gaze has found something more interesting and he has chosen to ignore the woman's comment. According to Pollock, "She is contrasted iconographically to the naked woman. She is denied the picturing of her desire; what she looks at is blank for the spectator. She is denied being the object of desire because she is represented as a woman who actively looks, rather than returning and confirming the gaze of the masculine spectator".<ref name="Pollock-pp50-90" />
Lorraine Gamman has suggested that a female gaze can be distinguished from that of a male through its displacing of [[Scopophilia|scopophilic]] power, not simply the inversion of the male gaze, which creates the possibility of a multiplicity of viewing angles. In fact, for Gamman, "the female gaze cohabits the space occupied by men, rather than being entirely divorced from it".<ref>{{citation | last = Gamman | first = Lorraine | contribution = Watching the detectives: the enigma of the female gaze | editor-last1 = Gamman | editor-first1 = Lorraine | editor-last2 = Marshment | editor-first2 = Margaret | title = The Female gaze: women as viewers of popular culture | page = 16 | publisher = Real Comet Press | location = Seattle | year = 1989 | isbn = 9780941104425 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Thus, for Gamman, the role of the female gaze is not to appropriate the traditional male form of "voyeurism;" its purpose is to disrupt the [[Phallocentric]] power of the male gaze by providing for other modes of looking.
[[Jay David Bolter]] and [[Richard Grusin]] suggest that Mulvey's "male gaze" coincides with "the desire for visual immediacy", the erasure of the medium for uninhibited interaction with the object portrayed, which feminist film theorists treat as "a male desire that takes an overt sexual meaning when the object of representation, and therefore desire, is a woman".<ref name="Remediation">{{citation | last1 = Bolter | first1 = Jay David | last2 = Grusin | first2 = Richard | contribution = Networks of remediation | editor-last1 = Bolter | editor-first1 = Jay David | editor-last2 = Grusin | editor-first2 = Richard | title = Remediation understanding new media | pages = 64–87 | publisher = MIT Press | location = Cambridge, Massachusetts | year = 1999 | isbn = 9780262024525 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>{{rp|79}} However, Bolter and Grusin consider their term "hypermediacy", the drawing of attention to the medium (or media) and the mediating processes present in a work, to be a manifestation of Gamman's female gaze because it "is multiple and deviant in its suggestion of multiplicity—a multiplicity of viewing positions and a multiplicity of relationships to the object in view, including sexual objects".<ref name="Remediation" />{{rp|84}} According to Bolter and Grusin, then, hypermediacy, much like the female gaze, works to disrupt the myopic and monolithic male gaze by offering more angles of viewing.
At the 2016 Toronto International Film Festival, [[Jill Soloway]], in her keynote address, tried to define the "female gaze" in film-making (available on YouTube).
The Indian photographer [[Farhat Basir Khan]] attributes the female gaze to anything that's been photographed by a woman which according to Khan is actually breaking the stereotypical view created by "male-constructed" photographs that have shown women in a certain light throughout the history of visual arts. <ref>{{cite web|title=From her perspective|url=http://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/art/From-her-perspective/article16988924.ece|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=30 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180602070404/http://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/art/From-her-perspective/article16988924.ece|archivedate=2 June 2018|df=}}</ref> The idea of female gaze was central to the exhibition curated by Khan titled 'Feminography' at the [[Indira Gandhi National Centre for the Arts]] in January 2017.
=== Oppositional gaze === [[bell hooks]], in her essay titled "The Oppositional Gaze: Black Female Spectatorship",<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=The Feminism and Visual Cultural Reader.|last=hooks|first=bell|publisher=Amelia Jones|year=|isbn=|location=New York: Routledge, 2003|pages=94–105|chapter=The Oppositional Gaze: Black Female Spectator|quote=|via=}}</ref> argues that Black women are placed outside of the "pleasure in looking" as an imaginary subject to the male gaze.<ref name=":0" /> In reading [[Laura Mulvey|Mulvey]]'s essay "Visual Pleasure and Narrative Cinema",<ref>{{Cite book|title=Media and Cultural Studies: Keywords|last=Mulvey|first=Laura|publisher=Meenakshi Gigi Durham and Douglas Kellner|year=|isbn=|location=2001; Malden, MA: Blackwell, 2006|pages=342–352|chapter=Visual Pleasure and Narrative Cinema|quote=|via=}}</ref> hooks states,"...from a standpoint that acknowledges race, one sees clearly why black women spectators not duped by mainstream cinema would develop an oppositional gaze".<ref name=":0" /> In relation [[Jacques Lacan|Lacan]]'s [[mirror stage]], during which a child develops self recognition and thus, the [[Ego ideal|ideal ego]], hooks takes up the oppositional gaze as a form of looking back, in search of the Black female body within the idealization of cinematic white womanhood.<ref name=":0" />
The absence of racial relations in the context of feminist theory around the "totalizing category [of] women" engages in a process of denial which refutes the reality that many feminist film critics structure their discourse around white women.<ref name=":0" /> As a working-class Black woman interviewed by hooks replied, "to see black women in the position white women have occupied in film forever...", is to see a 'transfer' without 'transformation'.<ref name=":0" /> The oppositional gaze, therefore, encompasses resistance as well as an understanding and awareness of the politics of race and racism via cinematic whiteness inclusive of the male gaze.<!-- any commentary on ''La Dame Indignee''? -->

{{Infobox theatre | name = Mariinsky Theatre | image = Spb 06-2012 MariinskyTheatre.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | image_map = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_map_caption= | address = 1 Theatre Square | city = [[Saint Petersburg]] | country = [[Russia]] | designation = | coordinates = {{coord|59|55|32|N|30|17|46|E|region:RU_type:landmark|display=title,inline}} | architect = [[Alberto Cavos]] | owner = | tenant = [[Mariinsky Ballet]]
Mariinsky Opera
[[Mariinsky Theatre Orchestra|Mariinsky Orchestra]] | operator = | capacity = | type = | opened = 2 October 1860 | reopened = | yearsactive = 1860–present | rebuilt = | closed = | demolished = | othernames = | production = | currentuse = | website = {{URL|www.mariinsky.ru}} | logo_image = Mariinsky Theatre Logo.png }} The '''Mariinsky Theatre''' ({{lang-ru|'''Мариинский театр'''}}, '''Mariinskiy Teatr''', also spelled '''Maryinsky''' or '''Mariyinsky''') is a historic theatre of [[opera]] and [[ballet]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]]. Opened in 1860, it became the preeminent music theatre of late 19th-century Russia, where many of the stage masterpieces of [[Tchaikovsky]], [[Mussorgsky]], and [[Rimsky-Korsakov]] received their premieres. Through most of the Soviet era, it was known as the '''Kirov Theatre'''. Today, the Mariinsky Theatre is home to the [[Mariinsky Ballet]], Mariinsky Opera and [[Mariinsky Theatre Orchestra|Mariinsky Orchestra]]. Since [[Yuri Temirkanov]]'s retirement in 1988, the conductor [[Valery Gergiev]] has served as the theatre's general director. ==Name== The theatre is named after [[Maria Alexandrovna (Marie of Hesse)|Empress Maria Alexandrovna]], wife of [[Alexander II of Russia|Tsar Alexander II]]. There is a bust of the Empress in the main entrance foyer. The theatre's name has changed throughout its history, reflecting the political climate of the time: {|Class="wikitable" style="width:65em; font-size:90%; line-height:1.2" !style="width:6%;"|From !style="width:6%;"|To !style="width:44%;"|Russian !style="width:44%;"|English |- |
